number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												An absolutely beautiful game with fluid animations and solid brawler mechanics.While there is very little in the way of weapon variety, you're still provided with a range of options for taking out enemies from your basic brawler combos to parrying and aerial throws, all of which are animated gorgeously. Despite being limited to one weapon, you do earn additional magic powers and movement skills, such as double jumps and wall clinging, as the game goes on, which help open up new areas to explore places you couldn't before.The majority of the skills you learn in the tutorial will be your bread and butter through a majority of the game. Thankfully, enemies later in the game do test everything you've learnt, so relying on a single tactic won't do you many favours, with some being only vulnerable to parries and others to magic attacks.Combined, the combat looks and feels great and doesn't outstay it's welcome for the 9 to 12 hours it takes to beat the game.The game also borrows a lot from RPGs with a level up system, side quests and a crafting mechanic, allowing you to build upgrades from blueprints dropped by enemies and found in chests. The upgrades usually add an additive or multiplicative effect to stats, item drops or health regeneration, which doesn't occur naturally otherwise.The entire game is fully voiced, which is an impressive feat for an indie title of this size. There are points where the dialogue feels forced, which can be chalked down to a problem with the script at points, but the main cast do a pretty spectacular job with their characters and help compliment the animation work nicely.If you have any experience with videogames in the past at all, I'd highly recommend playing the game on the Tough difficulty setting, as the Normal difficulty is far too forgiving. The Tough difficulty gives you a good reason to buy and use consumables without piling things on enough to make you ever feel overwhelmed.Mentioning the game is programmed and animated by one person is a moot point, but one that's bound to be brought up if you read up on the game on other sites or reviews. The game easily oozes enough quality and polish that, outside some late game cutscenes, you'd never realise or believe one man did all that work over four years.I highly recommned this game so much, that I even spent time writing out a review of this length. Hopefully, it's filled with enough information to make you consider trying it out. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												After reading some positive reviews for this game, I decided to pick it up during the Steam Winter Sale and I am glad I did! The core of this game is the fighting and the fighting is great. You will be flying around the maps (literally) swinging your sword hitting enemies. It looks awesome, feels awesome, and is just awesome in every other category. The game also gives you several combos that each have their uses. Your companion, Fidget, also gets a few kool spells that can combo with your sword swinging. To be fair, let's throw in a downside. Fidget's damage is so minute compared to Dust's damage until the very end of the game where items give crazy bonuses to her damage. I really just used her spells for style (and it does stagger enemies for a little bit so that's always helpful). This game also looks beautiful and has great music. However, we need to address the graphics style. The characters are all anthropomorphic animals (I wanna say they most resemble a cross between a dog and a fox?) in an anime style which may turn some people off. Back to the music part, I would look forward to completing an area just to listen to the World Map music.The game has a wide variety of settings to customize to your personal preferences and your computer specs. There were a few moments (mostly towards the end) where my frame rate took a hit but with the amount of particle effects and action going on, it was understandable and it didn't last long. The controls are solid and can be played with a keyboard/mouse or a controller. The game even allows you to switch your input method on the fly and which adjust tooltips accordingly so. Now for a quick lists of things I did not like. - Fidget's damage is lackluster until the latter parts of the game.- You will almost never be at full health. I played on the Tough difficulty and was always around ~25% health the whole game.- Some monsters deal absurd damage (one particular enemy will just snipe you with it's tentacle and pretty much insta-kill you). No matter how much health or defense I had, enemies just seemed to kill me in just 1 or 2 hits.- There are some exploding enemies which resemble Bombs from Final Fantasy which are just annoying.- The healing system is questionable. You have a hotkey for healing items (food) which instantly refill your health. You can spam this button as long as you have enough food to eat. It makes the game very easy if you have ready to eat.- Last one, I promise. In some parts of the game, the camera just seems way too close to Dust. I wouldn't mind it if the camera just moved back a little bit so I can where I am going.(Please note that although these are things I see as problems with the game, the pros FAR outweigh these cons. These issues will rarely take away from the game.)

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												After just one playthrough, Dust: An Elysian Tail proves to be an absolutely beautiful game with a very satisfying combat system. The amount of destruction you can do by the end of the game is mind-blowing. It's basically an action RPG with the elements of a Metroidvania and it works extremly well. The game is also very user-friendly in terms of sidequests and treasure hunting, making a complete run of the game really fun. I still have a few treasures left to find, but I'm very close. The story is great, the soundtrack is great, and the characters are great. Although, I will say that some cutscenes do go on for a long time. You can skip them, but for anyone who enjoys a good story, there's a ton of dialogue in this game, despite the game being fairly short for an RPG. So, be prepared for that. If I had to say one negative about the game, it's the fact that at times, when there are a ton of enemies and attacks on screen, it's hard to keep track of where you are. This isn't a dealbreaker, but I did die a few times due to now knowing where I was. Overall, if you're looking for a very solid RPG with beautiful art, an engaging story and cathartic combat, look no further than Dust.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												First off let's get the obvious stuff out of the way: This game is gorgeous, and the audio is amazing. Okay.Dust surprised me with it's ongoing and expansive story, i really just thought it would be your standard 2D sidescroller (which i was perfectly ok with given it's beauty) but was gifted with this RPG-like story. The voice acting is on par with games like Final Fantasy, and the characters really resonate with emotion and believability. While the gameplay it's self isn't breaking any new ground, it is a solid sidescroller with RPG elements to the character progression. I firmly believe that if Nintendo had had the technology we have today, this is what 90% of the library for the NES would have looked like. It is an instant classic, and a game that i tell dozens of people about per day (i work in a call center and sell more Steam games than i do our own products haha. OOPS.) So take it from me, Tech Support Agent #52146, this game is for you if you ever played a NES game and smiled. Also, if you like cutesy creates.. the nimbat Fidget is just friggin adorable.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												10/10I have played this games for hours upon hours now. The graphics, for being such a simple game, are very, very well done. The characters are fun, creative, and delightfully comedic. There is also quite a bit of story to the game.The puzzles are not the most difficult, but they are fun. The game gets progressively more challenging as time goes on, but it is still not difficult to play. So anyone that plays will have a good chance to learn the game while it is still simple enough to play.I love the story, I love the characters, and most of all I love Fidget.(Edit 1/2)As of now, I've completed both Tough and Hardcore mode of the game. I'm deathly in love with the story, and more so with the ending. The challenge in Hardcore is NOT to be underestimated and it is seriously something that demands the utmost effort. The mastery trinkets at the end (the x2 Attack and x2 Defense) I would recommend the Wisdom pendant (x2 Defense) for the sake of surviving against Gaius in Hardcore mode.  Hardcore genuinely presents the most challenge I've had with a game in years.I've put in a total of about 40 hours into this game. There isn't, I confess, much replay value unless you're a challenge ♥♥♥♥♥ and you just really enjoy burning your way through a game on the hardest difficulty. The Lightning attack is probably a bit overpowered, even in Hardcore because of how easy it is to distance-target enemies and just hide on ledges that they can't reach you on when you link it with DUST STORM.All in all, this is my favorite game of 2015. Absolute, hands down. I highly recommend this game. I've played "big name release" titles like DMC that present fewer hours of play time than this.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												I don't think I can possibly recommend this game enough. It has excellent fast-paced gameplay, a short, straightforward yet deep and moving storyline, and most of all it has beautiful graphics with an excellent soundtrack. There are very few games that come this close to perfection, although it does has it's drawbacks. Certain characters can get tedious at times (I.E. Fidget) and  the combat system makes you heavily rely on evading and parrying more than anything else, and then there's the terrible possibility that the story and environment just don't suit your taste (Shame on you). Still, this is a really great game and everyone should give it a chance.Pros:   +Exellent fast-past gameplay, even if it's a bit hack-and-slash   +Allows you to develop your own custom build (to a certain extent)   +Exellent Soundtrack and Graphics   +Story is deep yet very easy to grasp   +-Cute characters (This may be a con depending on how you view this)   +Plenty of extra stuff to do to keep you busy, or you can speed through the entire thingCons:   -Need to rely more on evasion/parrying heavily   -Take massive damage late-game, even if you pool all your stat gems into defence   -You may find some characters annoying

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an elegant masterpiece.I actually bought this game on a mere whim, when I felt I wanted to try a new game, and this was on sale, so I decided to give it a shot. That has turned out to be one of the best game purchases of my life.So, why should you buy Dust: An Elysian Tail?First, the beautifully hand-crafted art is to die for. Second, as an action-packed platformer, the combat system is easy to learn but hard to master. You'll take awhile before you learn how to snag achievements like That's More Like It (Successfully complete a 1000+ hit combo) and The Stuff of Legends (Earn a Four-Star Rating in EVERY Challenge Arena), which makes it that little bit sweeter when you do.Third, apart from it's main storyline, there are many side-quests and secret locations to conquer and discover. Looking to uncover them all? Don't stop at 100% completion, it goes up to 117% completion. Amen.Last, but certainly not least, is the compelling storyline. There is a fine balance between humour and drama. You'll be hooked to follow the storyline up till the grand finale.Your parents probably told you to never talk to strangers, but I need you to trust me and do yourself a favour by purchasing and playing this game. You have no idea what you're missing out on if you don't.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I played through the game on Hardcore difficulty and enjoyed it. This is one of the best Indie games I have played. It has amazing artwork, great sence of humour and intersting characters. The story keeps you interested and you will want to know what will happen next, who is everybody and why things are happening. There are some references from other games (some are very well hidden) but not too hard to find if you use your head. Some negative points worth noting:I used xbox 360 controller to play and sometimes found that using analog stick to perform certain actions might cause you to do the wrong move. This is really annoying when you try to do trials where time and precision is crucial. I failed so many times when my character jumped instead of ducking and sliding or vice versa. I do however recommend playing with a controller even though keyboard and mouse works great, controller is still better.You will probably want to play it once because once you know the story there will be no point in playing again so if you played on casual you are simply wasted your time because it was too easy and you can finish it in few hours. There are, however, 25 sidequestes which you can complete and you won't get all achievements unless you do them all.Difficulty curve is not ideal. On harcode mode is really hard to start that will cause you to die over and over until you reach some levels or keep killing same enemies over and over. Later on it when you level up and get some items it becomes too easy. Simply be patient and you will enjoy the game without any annoying issues.Overall it is great game that is worth your time. I spent over 30 hours and got all the achievements.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Simply enchanting.What makes a truly great game? Well, in my personal opinion, a great game isn't about showing off the best graphics or having mass appeal. A great game, to me anyway, is a true work of art and that's what I feel this particular one is. The visuals and soundtrack are two of the things I find to be the most remarkable about Dust: An Elysian Tail. Gazing into the vistas and listening to the BGM almost made me feel like I was playing one of my old all time favorite games ever. Legend of Mana. I felt that every track complimented each scene well and was enjoyable to even just stop and listen to for a moment without being too distracting at the same time.The movement and combat are fluid and easy to grasp. You rarely ever feel like the game is ever at fault for any mishaps. Combat is very fast paced and stylized like in Devil May Cry. It even has it's own little combo counter for those who like to show off their skills. And while your arsenal of attacks might feel a little limited, watching the protagonist soar back and forth across the screen in a whirlwind of blood and death never seems to get old. Level progression is also well balanced. I never felt like finding the newest upgrade for my equipment ever impacted the difficulty of the game too drastically or was ever essential for advancing in the story. Speaking of, the story isn't too bad either. The dialogue between the protagonist and the inhabitants of Falana(the in-game world) is humorous and well written, yet there have also been a couple parts that jerked a tear out of me too. As a bonus, throughout the entire game, you'll find lots of little references and easter eggs from other games dotted out through each map, if you're a big gamer of course.  It's also refreshing to play a game that doesn't require you to make some kind of moral decision at every turn for once. If there were anything at all I'd change about Dust, it would probably be the way the NPCs were animated. I just felt that the animations between the NPCS and protagonist clashed a little bit and while it's not a big detail, it certainly would have added some polish to an already amazing game.So if you've got some scratch to spare and enjoy games that are more art and less mass appeal, this one is definitely worth picking up.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												This has probably become one of my favourite Metroidvanias on Steam (along with Valdis Story)! Not something I'd hold as the hallmark of game design, but the combat is so good that it makes playing the whole game really fun, despite being somewhat monotonous, otherwise.Valdis Story is a very methodical metroivania with a pretty deep combat system (with combo-cancelling, lot's of timed dodges and parries, etc.) and tough, pattern based boss fights that you really need to try to learn and pay attention to learn the game, and it's incredibly satisfying when you do!Dust: An Elysian Tail, on the other hand, is very loose. You fight dozens of enemies at once, if necessary, but your attacks are very large and throw enemies all over the place, making you feel like a badass! Fighting these many enemies at once is really satisfying, if not a bit too chaotic to be challenging (in a fair way). The crux of it is that your sword attacks have a rather wide range, and you have the ability to suck enemies in. With that, plus a helpful magic, you'll easily manage dozens of enemies, racking up combos of 1000+, at times. In short, you're like a ♥♥♥♥ing tornado. With fire/lightning at the center.And that's enough, surprisingly enough. The combat is very fluid and looks awesome!Most of the game will be you tearing throw many enemies at once. However, there are different enemies, some of which can be tough, and require more attention, and parrying to defeat. Which helps a lot to keep things somewhat fresh!The most disappointing thing was the boss fights. They're mostly really easy. And I was playing on the highest difficulty. On the whole, the game is fairly easy, if you take your time to explore and learn how to deal with different enemies. Only one of the bosses was somewhat hard to me, requiring a few tries, making me switch my tactics a bit.The game had one frustrating element, which was the environmental hazards, in some places. These do a ton of damage, often killing you in 1 or 2 hits... But, otherwise, the game was very fair. With one exception (graveyard), checkpoints were very kindly placed, so you never lose much progress on death.The game as a lot of other features, like a crafting system, and fairly wide equipment system, leveling up, etc. etc. These all worked pretty well, giving you several options to tackle your progression, but they couldn't really be a focus for any player. They're there to support the combat and keep the progression up, nothing more.As a metroidvania, especially regarding the abilities you gain, it wasn't spectacular (well, the abilities weren't very interesting), but the exploration element is very present, and in a good way!The game has side-quests that cannot be completed when you first get them, making you go back to the places you've been to after you get more abilities and... have grown overpowered. Going back to previously hard areas and feeling like a God is ... well, it makes you feel like a God. (The leveling system is exponential which explains how much more powerful you get after each area)There are several references to other games, which are nice, and lots of treasure and blueprints to help you get stronger.The map system is also very generous, telling you the screens where you've missed something with an icon so you can easily check back later and know more or less what you may be missing.´I don't want to write much more about it. The game is beautifully drawn and has some nice screen effects (distortions, for the most part), with one of the most fun combat systems around. So definitely give it a go!Not the most challenging game, so try Valdis Story if you're looking for a more difficult game.

ProsThis game was made with love and you can feel itCombat systemYou actually feel stronger when you level upCool power-upsThe leveling system isn't a grindfestConsI would like 1 or more 2 combos to be availableIt takes some time to see how great this game isGraphicsBeautiful drawn scenarios and charactersGameplayThe leveling system is simple and welcomingFull controller support, 0 complaintsMonsters drop loot like gear and materials you can use to craft even more gear. Gear makes a huge, but positive, differenceAudioNicely craftedThe dialog voices were good but not amazingFinal ThoughtsI didn't know anything about this game when I picked it up and, to be honest, I was just looking to finish it. However, the more I played, the more I loved this game. I found out it was developed by one guy and, wow, amazing job. Kudos for you, sir.I had a great time playing this game. It went from a game I wanted to finish, to a game I wanted to fully complete and enjoy the most of it. It grew inside me.Everything is simple enough but in a good way.This game tries to be many things. An adventure, a platformer, a RPG and an action hack and slash game. You know what? It works. Its like a perfect mixture of those ingredients that results in a tasty, sweet game that I'm sure will also grow inside you.Recommended!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #52 - Dust: An Elysian TailI found Dust to be a really easy game to pick up and enjoy. The gameplay consists of a mix of exploration and combat.  Combat is pretty fun.  It does involve a lot of button mashing, but there are lots of different button combinations you can use to perform different attacks.  It starts out pretty easy but once you start getting into your first boss battles, it will start to present a challenge.  But really casual players will appreciate the inclusion of a difficulty setting in the options.  It does include an easy mode for people who just want to enjoy the story without too much of a challenge.I'd say the strongest part of the game is definitely the art. The characters and backgrounds are very well done.  Dust is a beautiful game, which is great given the emphasis on exploration.   There is some platforming involved as you explore, but I didn't find any of it particularly difficult.  Dust really seems to go out of it's way to be broadly accessible, without feeling dumbed down.This is going to end up being a short review, as I'm really challenged to come up with anything I didn't like about Dust.  Everything from the art to the music and sound to the fighting and the story just all come together.  This really feels like a game that anyone can enjoy.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Ok so first ill start off by saying i got this in the steam summer sale, somwhere in the £2 zone, and after playing this game i would have gladly paid full price for this, and got it sooner if i knew what was in stock.Ok so the story centers around "Dust" who has 2 companions, "Fidget" and his Sword "Ahrah", who go on a journey to help "Dust" Discover his past, and i have to say the character development and interaction between these characters and a few ofther characters, seems so very real.Where as alot of platformers the only speech you seem to have is getting told the mission objective and the rest story line, Dust:An Elysian Tail, has pleanty of moments where you will laught at what there characters are saying, and alot of the Speech you will listen to rather than skip.Oh and its fully voiced, i think that its a job well done with the voice acting overall, some poor bits here and there but over all the voice acting is rather good.Now Down to GAMEPLAY, the combat is very fast paced and very fun,you gain new abilities all the way through the game and there not too far spread out that it feels like you should already have a certain ability, going along with this you can go back through the levels and unlocked new areas that you previously couldn't.And although you do only have the 1 weapon through out the game, there is pleanty of items you can get to give you boosts in lots of different stats. Mixed in with this is a very simple yet fun to use crafting system, which just consists of gathering blueprints and materials, and using the materials to create the item on the blueprint, which you can then equip.And last although this isnt all that important i did find this a fun extra to the game, there is hidden cages through out the world which have a little surprise in them.(Dont want to spoil whats in them)So basically if you havent realised yet, i really really like this game, and i wish i had gotten it sooner.So if your debating on weather to get it or not, i would just say, give it ago, im sure you'll enjoy it if you give it a chance.Also We need a sequel, so buy it anyway =)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Step into the shoes of Dust, another hero with amnesia, and travel a Metroidvania-esque world to slay monsters, talk to NPCs and find hidden treasures!The gameplay is, all in all, rather simple. You run around, jump and kill a lot of stuff. You kill stuff by swinging your talking sword and employing the abilities of your flying squirrel-thingy Fidget, which sometimes bears resemblance to such annoying sidekicks like Navi from the Legend of Zelda.The fighting itself is pretty simple. Your standard attack is a 3-hit combo, on the ground and in the air. Combine with your special ability and your sidekick you create some nice combos. You will also learn some new moves along your way, but they're primarily for traversing the world, which - in best Metroidvania-manner - has a lot of places you can't get through until you have the ability needed for it.If you want to explore and get absolutely everything, you'll have to do a LOT of backtracking, but you can also use teleport stones that make it a bit easier.Besides fighting and finding treasures you'll also encounter many NPCs you can talk to. Talking might reveal information and sidequests. You will also get experience from talking to NPCs, which I find a really nice little feature.Crafting is also present. Defeating enemies or opening treasure chests might get you blueprints and material to craft the items from the blueprints. To make that a bit easier you can sell material to the shopkeepers, who then add them to their inventory, which makes it possible to purchase those materials from them. Quite handy if you can't or don't want to find them on your way around.The game looks absolutely incredible btw. Beautiful levels accompanied by a nice soundtrack.Not a big fan of the character design though. I don't mind antropomorphic animals in the slightest, but I just didn't like how many of them looked.Also worth mentioning is the voice acting, as it's quite good. Not all were that good, but mostly it was very well done.All things considered a really nice game with a decent story, good gameplay and gorgeous visuals :)

												I discovered this game from a friend. The artwork looked fantastic, the setting and story sounded fun, and the game play seemed like a classic nod to Metroid and Castlevania. Started playing and was instantly hooked! The controls were smooth and intuitive, game mechanics were fun and familiar, and there were some delightful surprises along the way too. And speaking of notes... the soundtrack rivals the art in terms of beauty. This is easily one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time. I highly recommend it and will definitely be revisiting it from time to time.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a masterpiece, plain an simple. The world of Dust is presented with amazing scenery and hand drawn and animated characters accompanied by beautiful music. You take control of an amnesic swordsman on a journey to discover himself and every character you meet along the way is voice acted and memorable. Not the least of is Fidget a character accompanies you the whole game and provides much of the game's needed comic relief. There is a real sense of joy as you uncover more of the story as you play, and help Dust learn more about himself (as well as hear what Fidget has to say about various encounters).Gameplay wise Dust is a 2D metroidvania platformer. As you slice baddies you earn experience which you can use to improve your stats as you see fit and equip and craft items to further enhance your stats. Over the course of the game you and Fidget also gain further abilities to allow more freedom in not only disposing of your enemies but also reaching new areas. Apart from the main story there are a number of side-quests as well as hidden arenas to test your skill. And it is all a blast to play. I would really recommend a gamepad to play, especially an XBox 360 Controller.The most impressive thing about Dust: An Elysian Tail is the fact that apart from the music, voice acting and part of the story, Dust was created, programmed and drawn entirely by one man,  Dean Dodrill. So in a way Dust is like an American equivalent of Cave Story. I know that may sound like a stretch, but honestly this game has brought me a lot of joy and fond memories and I would highly recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail looks a little different than your typical action/adventure game, but its similarities should keep you around for a while.The game begins with you, "Dust" waking up to find yourself in a forest with no memory of your past or how you ended up at your location. As if it wasn't strange enough, a magical sword finds you and speaks to you, followed by a small, annoying creature. They accompany you on a journey to find who you are, why you awoke with no memory, and why you were chosen to wield a magical sword.Presentation: 8/10The story isn't groundbreaking but is enough to get anyone to wonder what's in store for a protagonist with amnesia as he travels through the country. Dust is a kind character, who helps those he can (if you complete the quests) until he finds his past. The game adequately tells the tale from start to finish, but you can never really tell how much of an impact you're making by the end.Graphics: 7.5/10Cute cartoon artstyle settles well and takes your mind off the fact that Dust: An Elysian Tail was designed and programmed by a single individual.Sound: 7.5/10The pleasant music never stuck itself in places unneeded, a good addition overall. The voice acting was good for some characters, but never made Fidget any less annoying.Gameplay: 8/10Fluid, fast-paced and with different options to attack your enemies, the combat was well received. There are many items to acquire, along with the secret non-playable characters hidden throughout the game. My only gripe is the hideous transitioning of the camera as you fly through the map.Overall: 7.8/10A good purchase if you're looking for some action/adventure. With only limited replayability, the game can keep you busy for several days before you find yourself with not much else to do, but for a well-polished game, its price is definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												This game wasn't quite what I expected.  It's one of those titles where the enemies are pretty tough & do a lot of damage, but are slow and telegraph their attacks.  Your character, on the other hand, is fragile and doesn't hit very hard, but can attack with great rapidity.  So, your only chance of winning (esp. on the higher difficulties) is to keep your foes stunlocked  with an all-out assault, chaining hits and special moves together to never give them an opening.  As I've stated before, I don't really like fighting games, where you have to pull off specific key combinations with millisecond timing.  This is pushing things a little, but I was still able to use the combos they had programmed in, which is fortunately not that many.  This does limit the depth of the system and mean the combats can get very same-y after a while, though.So, it feels kind of incongruous.  Your protagonist is basically a walking abattoir, chewing through monsters with gusto.  Except he's also supposed to be a rabbit, I guess?  And all the other characters are cartoon animals too?  The story similarly veers back and forth between srs bzns and light-hearted banter.  It doesn't help matters that the game is one of the worst offenders in the Cutesy Sidekick That Never Shuts Up category.The art and animation are top-notch, considering this is a small-budget title.  It's not quite up there with the Odin Spheres of the world, but damn close.  The whole game is a bit on the short side, and probably much shorter still if you don't bother  hunting down all the sidequests and collecting everything.  That said, I had a lot of fun with it, and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys action-RPGs.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Ok so first ill start off by saying i got this in the steam summer sale, somwhere in the £2 zone, and after playing this game i would have gladly paid full price for this, and got it sooner if i knew what was in stock.Ok so the story centers around "Dust" who has 2 companions, "Fidget" and his Sword "Ahrah", who go on a journey to help "Dust" Discover his past, and i have to say the character development and interaction between these characters and a few ofther characters, seems so very real.Where as alot of platformers the only speech you seem to have is getting told the mission objective and the rest story line, Dust:An Elysian Tail, has pleanty of moments where you will laught at what there characters are saying, and alot of the Speech you will listen to rather than skip.Oh and its fully voiced, i think that its a job well done with the voice acting overall, some poor bits here and there but over all the voice acting is rather good.Now Down to GAMEPLAY, the combat is very fast paced and very fun,you gain new abilities all the way through the game and there not too far spread out that it feels like you should already have a certain ability, going along with this you can go back through the levels and unlocked new areas that you previously couldn't.And although you do only have the 1 weapon through out the game, there is pleanty of items you can get to give you boosts in lots of different stats. Mixed in with this is a very simple yet fun to use crafting system, which just consists of gathering blueprints and materials, and using the materials to create the item on the blueprint, which you can then equip.And last although this isnt all that important i did find this a fun extra to the game, there is hidden cages through out the world which have a little surprise in them.(Dont want to spoil whats in them)So basically if you havent realised yet, i really really like this game, and i wish i had gotten it sooner.So if your debating on weather to get it or not, i would just say, give it ago, im sure you'll enjoy it if you give it a chance.Also We need a sequel, so buy it anyway =)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an elegant masterpiece.I actually bought this game on a mere whim, when I felt I wanted to try a new game, and this was on sale, so I decided to give it a shot. That has turned out to be one of the best game purchases of my life.So, why should you buy Dust: An Elysian Tail?First, the beautifully hand-crafted art is to die for. Second, as an action-packed platformer, the combat system is easy to learn but hard to master. You'll take awhile before you learn how to snag achievements like That's More Like It (Successfully complete a 1000+ hit combo) and The Stuff of Legends (Earn a Four-Star Rating in EVERY Challenge Arena), which makes it that little bit sweeter when you do.Third, apart from it's main storyline, there are many side-quests and secret locations to conquer and discover. Looking to uncover them all? Don't stop at 100% completion, it goes up to 117% completion. Amen.Last, but certainly not least, is the compelling storyline. There is a fine balance between humour and drama. You'll be hooked to follow the storyline up till the grand finale.Your parents probably told you to never talk to strangers, but I need you to trust me and do yourself a favour by purchasing and playing this game. You have no idea what you're missing out on if you don't.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #52 - Dust: An Elysian TailI found Dust to be a really easy game to pick up and enjoy. The gameplay consists of a mix of exploration and combat.  Combat is pretty fun.  It does involve a lot of button mashing, but there are lots of different button combinations you can use to perform different attacks.  It starts out pretty easy but once you start getting into your first boss battles, it will start to present a challenge.  But really casual players will appreciate the inclusion of a difficulty setting in the options.  It does include an easy mode for people who just want to enjoy the story without too much of a challenge.I'd say the strongest part of the game is definitely the art. The characters and backgrounds are very well done.  Dust is a beautiful game, which is great given the emphasis on exploration.   There is some platforming involved as you explore, but I didn't find any of it particularly difficult.  Dust really seems to go out of it's way to be broadly accessible, without feeling dumbed down.This is going to end up being a short review, as I'm really challenged to come up with anything I didn't like about Dust.  Everything from the art to the music and sound to the fighting and the story just all come together.  This really feels like a game that anyone can enjoy.

Posted: July 27, 2016
												This has probably become one of my favourite Metroidvanias on Steam (along with Valdis Story)! Not something I'd hold as the hallmark of game design, but the combat is so good that it makes playing the whole game really fun, despite being somewhat monotonous, otherwise.Valdis Story is a very methodical metroivania with a pretty deep combat system (with combo-cancelling, lot's of timed dodges and parries, etc.) and tough, pattern based boss fights that you really need to try to learn and pay attention to learn the game, and it's incredibly satisfying when you do!Dust: An Elysian Tail, on the other hand, is very loose. You fight dozens of enemies at once, if necessary, but your attacks are very large and throw enemies all over the place, making you feel like a badass! Fighting these many enemies at once is really satisfying, if not a bit too chaotic to be challenging (in a fair way). The crux of it is that your sword attacks have a rather wide range, and you have the ability to suck enemies in. With that, plus a helpful magic, you'll easily manage dozens of enemies, racking up combos of 1000+, at times. In short, you're like a ♥♥♥♥ing tornado. With fire/lightning at the center.And that's enough, surprisingly enough. The combat is very fluid and looks awesome!Most of the game will be you tearing throw many enemies at once. However, there are different enemies, some of which can be tough, and require more attention, and parrying to defeat. Which helps a lot to keep things somewhat fresh!The most disappointing thing was the boss fights. They're mostly really easy. And I was playing on the highest difficulty. On the whole, the game is fairly easy, if you take your time to explore and learn how to deal with different enemies. Only one of the bosses was somewhat hard to me, requiring a few tries, making me switch my tactics a bit.The game had one frustrating element, which was the environmental hazards, in some places. These do a ton of damage, often killing you in 1 or 2 hits... But, otherwise, the game was very fair. With one exception (graveyard), checkpoints were very kindly placed, so you never lose much progress on death.The game as a lot of other features, like a crafting system, and fairly wide equipment system, leveling up, etc. etc. These all worked pretty well, giving you several options to tackle your progression, but they couldn't really be a focus for any player. They're there to support the combat and keep the progression up, nothing more.As a metroidvania, especially regarding the abilities you gain, it wasn't spectacular (well, the abilities weren't very interesting), but the exploration element is very present, and in a good way!The game has side-quests that cannot be completed when you first get them, making you go back to the places you've been to after you get more abilities and... have grown overpowered. Going back to previously hard areas and feeling like a God is ... well, it makes you feel like a God. (The leveling system is exponential which explains how much more powerful you get after each area)There are several references to other games, which are nice, and lots of treasure and blueprints to help you get stronger.The map system is also very generous, telling you the screens where you've missed something with an icon so you can easily check back later and know more or less what you may be missing.´I don't want to write much more about it. The game is beautifully drawn and has some nice screen effects (distortions, for the most part), with one of the most fun combat systems around. So definitely give it a go!Not the most challenging game, so try Valdis Story if you're looking for a more difficult game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #52 - Dust: An Elysian TailI found Dust to be a really easy game to pick up and enjoy. The gameplay consists of a mix of exploration and combat.  Combat is pretty fun.  It does involve a lot of button mashing, but there are lots of different button combinations you can use to perform different attacks.  It starts out pretty easy but once you start getting into your first boss battles, it will start to present a challenge.  But really casual players will appreciate the inclusion of a difficulty setting in the options.  It does include an easy mode for people who just want to enjoy the story without too much of a challenge.I'd say the strongest part of the game is definitely the art. The characters and backgrounds are very well done.  Dust is a beautiful game, which is great given the emphasis on exploration.   There is some platforming involved as you explore, but I didn't find any of it particularly difficult.  Dust really seems to go out of it's way to be broadly accessible, without feeling dumbed down.This is going to end up being a short review, as I'm really challenged to come up with anything I didn't like about Dust.  Everything from the art to the music and sound to the fighting and the story just all come together.  This really feels like a game that anyone can enjoy.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												This game.. this game man.Dust: An Elysian Tail is a very mysterious game at the beginning, of which then things slowly unfold and make sense at a fair pace.  You'll constantly want to know how or for the matter why Dust is here and why he's able to do all these moves and fight like a warrior.  Anything described story wise is a serious spoiler and you really, really, really do not want to spoil this amazing game so it's being skipped.Gameplay wise it's a hack n slash with some RPG elements thrown in that actually mix well.  You have your health, stamina to do specific abilties, can craft items once you find a blacksmith, sell materials to a shop owner so they can restock up on them for you to buy later.  Obviously you level up too, where you can set in skill gems to tailor towards what you want to have on a high priority.  Still gotta put in some gems on the lower leveled ones in order to keep building up Dust to a powerhouse.There's plenty of sides to do, things to unlock and discover, all the while enjoying the incredibly detailed and well drawn art.  The art alone is a very colorful and well done style that is impressive for a mostly one man game.  Almost could say it inspires some to get into drawing.Don't let all the talking anthro animal stuff fool you, it's like An American Tail, movies like that of which could have been some inspriation to having these type of characters.  So it's not because the creator is some furry or furries in general, just don't.  Don't let that one single word sneer you away from this game.  You'll regret it, heavily.It's hard to give this a 9/10, it's just so damn well made and entirely perfect, including the port to pc.  A quick note about the pc port. It's amazing what can be done if you take your time doing it, not rushing it like some of these major ass♥♥♥♥ companies do today with their half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ports to pc from console.10/10 solid, it deserves that well.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most fun games I've ever played. It combines a compelling story full of interesting characters with a style of gameplay that's challenging while never feeling tedious or boring. This game's got an atmosphere of adventure that makes the world of Falana one that you want to explore and discover more about. The movement and combat feel impressively fluid and help to further draw you into the environment. Everything seems to happen at a perfect pace, whether it be leveling up, gaining new skills, or moving forward in the story. There are several sidequests in addition to the main one that will introduce you to even more of the world's inhabitants and locations. Additional features like the crafting system, trial courses, and hidden secrets all add value and fun to the game experience.The amount of work put into this game is obvious from the quality and detail of every aspect. The art and music styles are fantastic--the look of characters, creatures, and environments, the background music, the visual and audio effects, and the cutscene animations all add to the mysterious and intriguing atmosphere. Better voicework than many other games, too, even if lines are a little slow sometimes (and even if recording quality for some characters isn't the best); the characters will draw you in and really make you feel like a part of the story. Once you pick up this game, you won't want to put it down.Bottom line: DEFINITELY worth your time. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Simply enchanting.What makes a truly great game? Well, in my personal opinion, a great game isn't about showing off the best graphics or having mass appeal. A great game, to me anyway, is a true work of art and that's what I feel this particular one is. The visuals and soundtrack are two of the things I find to be the most remarkable about Dust: An Elysian Tail. Gazing into the vistas and listening to the BGM almost made me feel like I was playing one of my old all time favorite games ever. Legend of Mana. I felt that every track complimented each scene well and was enjoyable to even just stop and listen to for a moment without being too distracting at the same time.The movement and combat are fluid and easy to grasp. You rarely ever feel like the game is ever at fault for any mishaps. Combat is very fast paced and stylized like in Devil May Cry. It even has it's own little combo counter for those who like to show off their skills. And while your arsenal of attacks might feel a little limited, watching the protagonist soar back and forth across the screen in a whirlwind of blood and death never seems to get old. Level progression is also well balanced. I never felt like finding the newest upgrade for my equipment ever impacted the difficulty of the game too drastically or was ever essential for advancing in the story. Speaking of, the story isn't too bad either. The dialogue between the protagonist and the inhabitants of Falana(the in-game world) is humorous and well written, yet there have also been a couple parts that jerked a tear out of me too. As a bonus, throughout the entire game, you'll find lots of little references and easter eggs from other games dotted out through each map, if you're a big gamer of course.  It's also refreshing to play a game that doesn't require you to make some kind of moral decision at every turn for once. If there were anything at all I'd change about Dust, it would probably be the way the NPCs were animated. I just felt that the animations between the NPCS and protagonist clashed a little bit and while it's not a big detail, it certainly would have added some polish to an already amazing game.So if you've got some scratch to spare and enjoy games that are more art and less mass appeal, this one is definitely worth picking up.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												So, where do I start... Possibly amongst the best games I've ever played in my entire life. It has some minor flaws, including a bug in the final boss fight which forces you to fight the boos all over again but other than that it's a masterpiece, a well polished PC port and a fine work of art. The soundtrack is relaxing and fits the game atmosphere very well. The combat is surprisingly satisfying, it combines brawling with hack and slash, in other words I can say that this is a Metroidvania ARPG Brawler. The combos are pretty good and the attack variety is somehow doesn't have alot of variety but it doesn't feel boring. The story is pretty great and overall that sells this game for me. I'm sure that pretty much anyone can enjoy this game and if you don't feel like paying full price for it, wait for a sale and then get it. I got it during a 50% sale but now I can safely say that the game is worth the full price, but this is only a matter of opinion. That said, please buy and play this, support the developer and MAYBE in the future there will be more games like this one.

												tl:dr - BUY IT.I'm a gamer for more than 15 years and this is one of my favorite games of all time.Graphics - Absolutely gorgeous. Music fits the graphics. Fighting system is simple but very enjoyable. It's fast, easy (From complexity standpoint) and visually appealing (everything explodes, shines, combos goes up to few hundrets). It's a metroidvania with a light RPG elements. Story is kinda generic, but it's satisfying, The only problem I had was how the characters looks like. Enemies looks relatively good, but NPC have that very cheap furry/cartoon style. I would rather like to see more "direct furry approach" or at least better quality of them  (shading, color pallete, more details, etc.). The only good looking NPC is Fidget (that flying cat/bat thingy... She's a Nimbat.). Characters are very good written. Oh, and Fidget is The Cutest character in video game I've ever seen. A want a plushie of her :3  (so I can keep her foreveeerrr....) 	 Anyway, Game took me about 13h to fully complete it, it's relatively hard on "hard difficulty", I haven't encountered any bugs or errors. I was playing it on Windows XP (Steam says it requires Vista/7). No slowdowns. In other words - Works good. Nothing much to say, really. It's a fantastic game, you should go and buy it. It's definitely worth your money.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Not too accustomed to writing reviews, so forgive me if something seems shortsighted or off-kilter here.That being said, I feel the need to give this game the recognition it deserves. It isn't often that a game comes along and leaves me with my mouth agape, shocked at the ratio of quality to manpower given to bring something to fruition. It was basically a one-man job, with a few exceptions to music, voice-acting and parts of the writing. This is not a game that makes you think that at all.Beautiful, strong, crisp, varied, colorful aesthetic that leads to gorgeous graphics. Music that evokes that classic, childlike sense of wonder of exploring, excitement, and adventure. Every time I would just bring up the map screen to teleport to a different area, it's evoke a powerful sense of nostalgia from me.Combatwise, everything is done with a blade and elemental ranged attacks, with ways to mix and match them all together. It's basically like a side-scrolling, platforming brawler with a nice degree of variation on enemy types and available tactics on taking them down.The story starts off somewhat simple, and feels like it's treading familiar territory for a little while, but quickly becomes more complex as it goes on. I won't give any spoilers, but needless to say, I wasn't expecting the game to do what it did later on, close to the finish.If I have any nitpicks, they are few. The lip-synching on the characters is a bit off, without much difference between the few mouth movements available. The voice-acting, while quite good overall, tends to give certain characters voices that don't quite fit, in addition to there being rather uneven sound quality amongst the performances. Still, these are both very minor issues, and I stopped noticing them after a while. It's just something I thought I should mention.Honestly, I could go on with this, but I don't want to keep you waiting. Overall, Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the best games I've played in quite a while. It was a stellar experience, and I think that anyone who is able to make a game like this almost by themselves definitely deserves support. I recommend it to just about anyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Sidescrolling RPG with very clean, beautiful graphics. Really good soundtrack, although it doesn't really stand out while playing. The character designs and their personalities are really well done, as is the dialogue. Lots of funny moments involving the main character (Dust) and his side-kick (Fidget.) The story is good but isn't very deep. Most of the gameplay revolves around sidequests or things not super directly related to the story's main premise. It's not until the last chapter that you even really learn the spoilers.The combat is very smooth and fluid, although it really starts to get repetitive a little over half-way in. The only real reason I didn't notice it so much is that you can build hits together for combos, and so I tended to always try to beat my previous record during fights. There's only a tiny bit of variation to the combat later on in the game, but it feels like it's introduced a bit too late and isn't all that different and exciting. I would have really liked a more complex system with more variations, but the combat is still really good just due to how smooth it is. The only negative I really have about the combat is that the game will often orient your characters automatically towards  an enemy or nearby object... so you'll be fighting something or trying to move into a specific position, and your character will somewhat auto-lock onto the thing it thinks you're trying to attack. It's fairly frustrating when it causes you to get hit during combat and break your combo.The last chapter drags on for an extremely long time as far as gameplay goes... it's a lot of fighting over and over. The story during this chapter really ramps up though, so it urges you to press on to see what it all means. The last boss battle is too ridiculous and drags on far beyond even the most patient person's attention span. It reminds me of Cave Story, where the game's flow is very well done, and ramps up as you progress.. but then the final battle is just way over the top to the point of being much harder than any other part of the game, and really frustrating.There are lots of things hidden away for you to find, namely keys that are used to unlock chests with goodies inside, and a bunch of "friends" which are just cameos of characters from other games. They're all fairly well hidden and it's fun to figure out how too get to keys that are just out of reach.Overall, this is a really well done game with a sizeable amount of gameplay. If you're trying to 100% it, you will spend many more hours trying to perfect  the challenge areas and get all the collectables.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Sidescrolling RPG with very clean, beautiful graphics. Really good soundtrack, although it doesn't really stand out while playing. The character designs and their personalities are really well done, as is the dialogue. Lots of funny moments involving the main character (Dust) and his side-kick (Fidget.) The story is good but isn't very deep. Most of the gameplay revolves around sidequests or things not super directly related to the story's main premise. It's not until the last chapter that you even really learn the spoilers.The combat is very smooth and fluid, although it really starts to get repetitive a little over half-way in. The only real reason I didn't notice it so much is that you can build hits together for combos, and so I tended to always try to beat my previous record during fights. There's only a tiny bit of variation to the combat later on in the game, but it feels like it's introduced a bit too late and isn't all that different and exciting. I would have really liked a more complex system with more variations, but the combat is still really good just due to how smooth it is. The only negative I really have about the combat is that the game will often orient your characters automatically towards  an enemy or nearby object... so you'll be fighting something or trying to move into a specific position, and your character will somewhat auto-lock onto the thing it thinks you're trying to attack. It's fairly frustrating when it causes you to get hit during combat and break your combo.The last chapter drags on for an extremely long time as far as gameplay goes... it's a lot of fighting over and over. The story during this chapter really ramps up though, so it urges you to press on to see what it all means. The last boss battle is too ridiculous and drags on far beyond even the most patient person's attention span. It reminds me of Cave Story, where the game's flow is very well done, and ramps up as you progress.. but then the final battle is just way over the top to the point of being much harder than any other part of the game, and really frustrating.There are lots of things hidden away for you to find, namely keys that are used to unlock chests with goodies inside, and a bunch of "friends" which are just cameos of characters from other games. They're all fairly well hidden and it's fun to figure out how too get to keys that are just out of reach.Overall, this is a really well done game with a sizeable amount of gameplay. If you're trying to 100% it, you will spend many more hours trying to perfect  the challenge areas and get all the collectables.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Dust... Ah, Dust...I could go on about the great writing and the beutiful world, but one is already apparent and the other would keep us here for hours, so I'll just talk about the gameplay.At it's core, Dust is actualy a simple game. there's your standard combo, and a couple branching moves including a launch, for bringing your fights to the sky, and a grab move, both of which are inisiated during your standard combo. In other words, your entire moveset is unlocked straight off, and is suprisingly small.So does this mean the game gets boreing fast? I suppose that depends on your own mentality. If your looking for a game with clear advancment such as unlockable skill trees, classes, and such, this is not for you. This game will get stale fast.If your looking for a game about mastery, this is the game for you. Just because Dust's moveset is small does not make it easy to master.You will spend hours upon hours honeing your ability to chain dust's various attacks together, with each passing minuet becoming more fluid and building up larger combos. You'll start learning when to group enemys up and when to pick out the straggelers. You'll learn which moves flow into the next. You'll learn about dodge-canceling. You'll learn about how to effectivly use the dust storm. You'll learn when to use Fidget's magic, untill eventualy you'll be wracking up 1000+ combos without batting an eye.Dust is, at it's core, a game about mastery. Thats all there really is to be said.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												So I got this based entirely on the recommendation of multiple friends.When I first saw the rating of E10, I figured they were out of their minds (At this point, I was starting the game, so I guess you can gather how much faith I have in my friends in total). They weren't.Keep in mind that action/platformer is about my least favorite genre ever. Happily, Dust doesn't go the route of making the platforming an exercise in pixel-perfection, but rather one of thinking ahead and planning. For me, it's much more satisfying to fail five times and know that there's still three routes I've not tested, than to fail fifteen times because I'm jumping a frame too soon.Now, the combat isn't overly complex, and it's very easy to get excessively powerful. But that's OK. I play most of my games on normal, at least at first. For this one, I felt pretty secure in adding a difficulty level. It doesn't QUITE match the game to my skill level then, but it made the game "difficult" enough that I could die if I stopped paying attention to my health. No idea how normal plays, but Tough feels about right for me anyway.The game draws you in with humor, but the real lasting attraction is that the game handles its characters as if they were actually people. It's not quite novel quality characterization here (let's be honest, very few characters have enough lines to develop much), but it's a refreshing change from action games where an NPC's toughness is directly related to how much profanity they can use.On the whole, I recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												I expected this to be a Disney-like side-scrollers (judging from the looks) but then I was in for a very nice surprise!Yes, this is a side-scroller with all of the traditional elements (secret rooms, keys, chests etc). However, it successfully mixes in some RPG elements such as levelling, gearing and crafting, always keeping everything very simple. The system is enjoyable and the combats as well with all the combos and abilities.Let's drop the line "story sucked, it was cliché" guys, it is getting cliché. There is at least one particular (very important!) non-cliché moment also. Some years ago, I would have been ashamed to admit that I've giggled many times with Fidget and that now I want a flying bat-cat pet, but I'm too old to care about sounding mature ("unleash the rainbow unicorns!" I say). Her humour IS CHILDISH but somehow in a good way, hard to explain. Voice acting was great in my opinion. Some dramatic moments are too short, but I guess it is a good compromise or else it could turn out annoying.I really disliked the design of the last 3 (of 6) areas, the background makes it hard to focus on the main character. Specially the 6th area, you simply CANNOT see him, and in the 5th I disabled weather effects. Otherwise, exploring the areas is fun.The game has 4 difficulties, and on the 3rd it was not too bad (except the very beginning). Some of the achievements are challenging, but not overly frustrating. You can finish the game with 115% completion, though there isn't an achievement for that (do you need one? we don't need one). You can find characters from other modern games locked in cages in secret areas *achievements bell rings*. That's some sort of homage to the modern classics, instead of the cliché "oh, I'm gonna pay homage to those games that everybody already paid homage to!!".Yes, you read it right.No homage to Mario. No homage to Link or Kirby. Suck. It. Cliché. Haters.Spoiler: I almost cried when I saw The Kid from Bastion and Tim from Braid. Right in the feels, I loved those games!Also, the guy did this on his own. Claps to him, claps to him...

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Created (designed and programmed) entirely by one person, Dust is a beautifully articulate love-letter to seminal games like Castlevania, Metroid, Ys and Devil May Cry. It’s full of secrets to uncover, areas to explore and enemies to kill in fantastically over-the-top ways. Getting a 1000-hit combo during a fight with dozens of badguys is not only immensely satisfying, it’s also almost effortless.The story may not be that unique or special, but it’s charming enough. The graphics are lush, and wonderfully animated, betraying how it was all done by a single individual’s hard work over the last three years. But the real soul of Dust is the confident combat system, which struts up to you the moment you start playing, takes you by the hand and encourages you to have fun. It’s not Bayonetta levels of sophistication , but it doesn’t have to be. The combination attacks are simple but empowering, launchers take you into the air with ease, and the Dust Storm (a kind of magic attack with several spells to uncover) has you stun-locking herds of enemies, experience points exploding around you like New Years fireworks.If games are a dialogue between the player and the game’s creator, then playing Dust is like sitting down with an old friend who’s back in town, full of fresh stories to tell and eager to reminisce with you about the good times.

It's a juicy mix of a 16 bit era platformers nostalgia spiced with RPG elements (it even has items crafting) and simple, yet satysfying combat system.Add an evergreen Metroidvania formula with it's every-nook-and-cranny exploration and you got yourself a game worthy of the highest praise.For me it's easily a 9 / 10

content:
Posted: June 6, 2013
												Buy? Likely. D:AET is a crowning achievement of a game that is made primarily by one person. Beautiful graphics with anthromorphic characters that harken back to the 90s era of gaming. Looks like furry lust, but it's not. Gameplay is a mix between Caslevania and Odin Sphere. Combat, though is a little repetitive after a while (projectiles change things up for a bit, but not for long). I hate how the game is deceptively easy, yet on tough difficulty, enemies can nearly one shot you. This isn't a huge problem since you find too many health items (perhaps this is deliberate), but this leads to a carefree "attack relentlessly and heal when you're hit gameplay" instead of a methodical approach like the best action games. I don't think this will bother most other gamers though. This requires an 360 Pad/Emulator, despite the "Full gamepad support" selling point.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This little game rewards persistence. I don't mean that in terms of grinding for gear, like in WoW, but in terms of spending a little bit of time unfolding the story... if you like a deep story little twists, and grippnig emotion. That is where this game shines, even if it takes a little to get into (maybe 2h before the story gets interesting).The other noteworthy thing to mention is the soundtrack, it's quite beautiful. No one else seems to talk about it here, so I wanted to make sure that it gets a mention.*yet to complete this game, but I spent a fair bit of time offline with it, thus the "short" amount of play time.***OK, I have 99% completed this game - with only 1 achievement outstanding, I wish that I had known this earlier. If you want to get all achievements in this game, start it on "tough" difficulty. I had decided that I wanted to 100% this game by about 1.5h - and didn't realise this was one of the requirements. So now i have another 11h of gameplay ahead of me to replay the entire game, just to get this one achievement.*The difference between 100% on Casual vs Tough is 17h vs 20h, if you play it through to completion the first time. it's probably more rewarding, too.The only complaint that I have about the game, is that you cannot skip the ending credits. Seriously.You get warned before the final boss battle that there is "no turning back once you go past this point" so you have to go and get everything in the world before you face him, if you want to 100% (actually about 117-120% I believe ingame).It's not a bad entry into the RPG series, as you always feel like you are progressing, never like you are grinding. actually, I levelled up faster than the enemies progressed, so by endgame, I was OP 1hitting almost everything, and 2shotting the hardest minions-type enemies in the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												This is a pretty ingenious game that has very good controls and a (predictable) really engaging story. You play as Dust, a warmblood who awakens with no memory of who he is or how he got there. He meets Fidget and a talking sword named Arrah and the three embark on an adventure to discover who he is and what he has to do.The game is a 2D/3D hybrid, much like the style of Shadow Complex. The game has a map system, hidden treasures, and powers that you must acquire in order to go back and find things you might have missed or need to progress.There's also an element of RPG, where by killing enemies, Dust earns XP and can upgrade his stats using skill gems, in the area of health, attack, defense, and Fidget.The combat is very enjoyable and is friendly to people who just like to button mash and those who like to use combo moves. The game rewards you with bonus XP for higher hit combos, so it's in your best interest to not get hit.You can earn money and materials to buy and craft new items to make Dust quite a force to be reckoned with.The voice acting is a little cheesy at some points, but it's pretty enjoyable, and most of the actors they got fit their parts.Some say if you don't really like Anime or "Furries" then you shouldn't play this game. I say, that's really not true. Whether or not you're a fan of either, the game is a lot of fun. It's probably a solid 10-11 hours of gameplay if you just want to get through the game, more if you are a completionist. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the few games I completed entirely, multiple times. I love this game for many reasons: the music is absolutely amazing, the background and characters are beautifully rendered and react to wind, rain and fighting, the combat has about 6-7 combos in total but you have so much freedom of movement that it feels like your pulling off 15-20 string combos, and the story is amazingly compelling. The sidekick you have through the game, Fidget The Nimbat, made me laugh many times and is a really good asset in combat. The combat rewards you for having long unbroken combo chains (there is an sidequest that has you get a 1000 hit combo) and reminds me of something Platinum Games would make. There are many little nods and easter eggs in the game from all of gaming history. They can be usuable items to the merchant to treasures you find in the world. The game really rewards exploration with items and money and health upgrades.The one weakness Dust: An Elysian Tail suffers from is the boss battles. It is usually one enemy that you fight , and it becomes trivial because you dodge their attacks and chain combos on them when there just standing there. The boss battles can be overlooked if you get really interested in the story.I would reccommend you play this game of the "Tough" difficulty, because normal is too easy for most people. The "Hardcore" difficulty is best saved for a second playthrough because you take more damage and enemies take less damage.I cannot reccommend this game enough to anyone that calls themselves a gamer. If you can get over the fact that the characters are anthromorphic animals and it is metroidvania styled , you will see a compelling story, beautiful design, music that is on par with Super Mario Galaxy, and a combat system that allows you to chain combos indefinitely.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												I expected this to be a Disney-like side-scrollers (judging from the looks) but then I was in for a very nice surprise!Yes, this is a side-scroller with all of the traditional elements (secret rooms, keys, chests etc). However, it successfully mixes in some RPG elements such as levelling, gearing and crafting, always keeping everything very simple. The system is enjoyable and the combats as well with all the combos and abilities.Let's drop the line "story sucked, it was cliché" guys, it is getting cliché. There is at least one particular (very important!) non-cliché moment also. Some years ago, I would have been ashamed to admit that I've giggled many times with Fidget and that now I want a flying bat-cat pet, but I'm too old to care about sounding mature ("unleash the rainbow unicorns!" I say). Her humour IS CHILDISH but somehow in a good way, hard to explain. Voice acting was great in my opinion. Some dramatic moments are too short, but I guess it is a good compromise or else it could turn out annoying.I really disliked the design of the last 3 (of 6) areas, the background makes it hard to focus on the main character. Specially the 6th area, you simply CANNOT see him, and in the 5th I disabled weather effects. Otherwise, exploring the areas is fun.The game has 4 difficulties, and on the 3rd it was not too bad (except the very beginning). Some of the achievements are challenging, but not overly frustrating. You can finish the game with 115% completion, though there isn't an achievement for that (do you need one? we don't need one). You can find characters from other modern games locked in cages in secret areas *achievements bell rings*. That's some sort of homage to the modern classics, instead of the cliché "oh, I'm gonna pay homage to those games that everybody already paid homage to!!".Yes, you read it right.No homage to Mario. No homage to Link or Kirby. Suck. It. Cliché. Haters.Spoiler: I almost cried when I saw The Kid from Bastion and Tim from Braid. Right in the feels, I loved those games!Also, the guy did this on his own. Claps to him, claps to him...

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												So I got this based entirely on the recommendation of multiple friends.When I first saw the rating of E10, I figured they were out of their minds (At this point, I was starting the game, so I guess you can gather how much faith I have in my friends in total). They weren't.Keep in mind that action/platformer is about my least favorite genre ever. Happily, Dust doesn't go the route of making the platforming an exercise in pixel-perfection, but rather one of thinking ahead and planning. For me, it's much more satisfying to fail five times and know that there's still three routes I've not tested, than to fail fifteen times because I'm jumping a frame too soon.Now, the combat isn't overly complex, and it's very easy to get excessively powerful. But that's OK. I play most of my games on normal, at least at first. For this one, I felt pretty secure in adding a difficulty level. It doesn't QUITE match the game to my skill level then, but it made the game "difficult" enough that I could die if I stopped paying attention to my health. No idea how normal plays, but Tough feels about right for me anyway.The game draws you in with humor, but the real lasting attraction is that the game handles its characters as if they were actually people. It's not quite novel quality characterization here (let's be honest, very few characters have enough lines to develop much), but it's a refreshing change from action games where an NPC's toughness is directly related to how much profanity they can use.On the whole, I recommend this game.

												An utterly gorgeous game with a compelling storyline.The combat, of course is not perfect but no game can truly be perfect.Rarely does a game get me attached to its characters, let alone anthropomorphic animals (Who'd have thunk it?) But really, this game is utterly amazing and it dictated my emotions throughout its entirety.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Created (designed and programmed) entirely by one person, Dust is a beautifully articulate love-letter to seminal games like Castlevania, Metroid, Ys and Devil May Cry. It’s full of secrets to uncover, areas to explore and enemies to kill in fantastically over-the-top ways. Getting a 1000-hit combo during a fight with dozens of badguys is not only immensely satisfying, it’s also almost effortless.The story may not be that unique or special, but it’s charming enough. The graphics are lush, and wonderfully animated, betraying how it was all done by a single individual’s hard work over the last three years. But the real soul of Dust is the confident combat system, which struts up to you the moment you start playing, takes you by the hand and encourages you to have fun. It’s not Bayonetta levels of sophistication , but it doesn’t have to be. The combination attacks are simple but empowering, launchers take you into the air with ease, and the Dust Storm (a kind of magic attack with several spells to uncover) has you stun-locking herds of enemies, experience points exploding around you like New Years fireworks.If games are a dialogue between the player and the game’s creator, then playing Dust is like sitting down with an old friend who’s back in town, full of fresh stories to tell and eager to reminisce with you about the good times.
