content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												The story of this game is around Dust, an anthropomorph that wakes up in the middle of a forest with no memories. You travel the lands trying to figure who you are while also helping out the people you meet along the way. I think the game focuses the most on its art and its story and although I don't have a harsh opinion on its game mechanic, I feel like there could've been more than just reworked art to same monsters-types.Combat & ControlThe combat system is based on a series of combos that is very easy to learn and different types of monsters & abilities are introduced along the way. The combos are easy to learn and pretty repetitive, but I didn't mind. Abilities were introduced throughout the game and are essential in being able to go back to previous maps to get previously obtainable treasure while also necessary to move ahead. I used an XBOX controller so it was a pretty easy ride for me and I liked playing this game when I just wanted to sit back in my chair and bash some buttons. The jumping was a bit annoying at first because I think it didn't have a "push down longer to jump for longer" mechanic so every jump was the same distance, even if you would give just a slight love tap to the jump button. Overall, I didn't mind the repetition of the combos and the new abilities   kept the combat and exploring the world a bit more interesting. As for the monsters, there were a lot of variety but there was definitely some "reskinning" going on as you enter different zone. For example, there was a type of monster that would explode if you got to close and in another "snowy" zone, it was just redrawn blue with snow on it. I thought it was cute, but it did leave something more to be desired in fighting new types of foes. Still, I'd like to emphasize that there was still a lot of variety and there's no harm in using the same monster-type at a higher skill area.World ExplorationAlthough there might have been some reskinning, I think I was able to look past it because each zone usually brought a new way to explore the world or puzzles that you had to solve to get the "treasures" scattered across the land. Like I mentioned earlier, you get introduced to new abilities and these abilities help you reach new places. For example, in the beginning of the game, Fidget points out a wall of vines that you have not yet learned how to climb and suggests we come back later. There are definitely some treasures that you would not be able to reach without certain learned abilities and would have to come back later to get them. And if you don't want to get them, that's fine too. The treasures are not vital in the end-game and are only for bragging rights and exploring the world. You also have to use these abilities and navigate around the map to get to the next zone so each area isn't just a mindless journey of button mashing.Art (Voice Acting, Graphics, Music)I've heard some people get really annoyed with the voice acting, and I can see where they're coming from. Fidget, your Navi-like companion, has a pretty squeaky voice and can be a little obnoxious to some and I found myself a little annoyed at some of the characters myself... Nonetheless, I think there was a lot of effort put into narrating pretty much every single line that is ever spoken in this game and I took the time to listen and read along. The backgrounds were pretty fantastic as well and there was just so much love put into every zone! I really loved the music as well and most them are very memorable! The only con is that there is just so much going on with aesthetic sometimes and there were some glitches with areas that were in complete darkness. Story Hey I admit it - I cried a bit and not just once! I can't really talk too much about the story without spoiling so I'll say this: they do have some cliche stories. Some "ideas" and plots didn't really resonate well with me either (e.g. Dust reacted differently than I expected to certain events, some plots didn't make too much sense with me, there were some missing plotholes...) Regardless, I thought it was quaint. Someone more critical than me might think the story was pretty sloppy... but who knows! Basically, this game isn't perfect but that didn't stop me from finishing it and obsessing over the hidden treasures... oh the hours I wasted! I suppose I'd recommend this game, but it may not be some people's cup of tea.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												TL;DR: It's worth the price and moreso if it's on sale. Is a good way to get into several kinds of games. Also includes a concept called "FUN".[Length - average]: This game is too short. Depending on how much of a completionist you are- my playtime would have been 3 hours less if I hadn't gotten lost a couple times while looking in every nook and cranny to get to some of the hidden locations for the lost friends before giving in to frustration and googling it. I also don't think it has a lot of replay value.[Difficulty - good]: There's not much to say about this, you've got the casual, medium, hard and 1-Hit KO levels. I would say some of the platforming and the 6 Trials are a challenge regardless of which mode you set the game to though.[Combat - excellent]: Being a sword-wielding-furry-assassin with a cat-like-bat-thing that can shoot lightning and fire, in addition to lightbulbs, who can then do screen-clearing combo attacks is kind of awesome...[Music/Sound - good]: I couldn't hear the actual music most of the time because of all the exploding enemies and other sound effects but when I did hear it, it matched the surroundings perfectly. The sound effects are also spot on and paired with the music, proceeded to make this 25 year old freak the heck out in Sorrowing Meadow (I would recommend not letting your young children see the spiders or mansions). [Voice Acting - good]: All the voices were decent which is saying something considering I try to mute that feature most of the time because of how bad it is usually. Fidget's voice actor, especially, nailed it in cutscenes with emotions or humor and her interactions with Dust really made me like the little sidekick.[Graphics - excellent]: I love the artstyle which is simple yet detailed at the same time and allows for even toasters like mine to run it flawlessly...unless you turn on weather and bloom effects which ruins the art and your framerate simultaneously![Story/Characters - excellent]: The story is very short and straightforward for the most part. It's not bad though because it's told well and the characters are what really brings it to life. I would almost describe the game's plot as a prologue or origin story because of...[The Ending - good]: Other than feeling empty because you have to find something else to play now- It satisfies you by wrapping up the main point of the game while giving you the craving for a sequel it so kindly dangles above you.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												After the short prologue we slip into the role of a fox called "Dust" who wakes up in the middle of the woods where we immediately have a conversation with "Ahrah", a talking sword. Right after "Fidget", the guardian of Ahrah appears. We find out that both of them will accompany us on our journey. And so we start our adventure. Initially very tutorial-like, we move forward getting familiar with controls and some important objects. As the game progresses, we get some useful abilities that allow us to explore the game to reach treasure chests or to do side quests. Sometimes we are in a region which contains sections we can't explore yet, once we have learned the required ability, we can return to this point. But not only we grow stronger, Fidget also learns some skills and is able to support us. Her abilities are very useful especially when it comes to a fight, we have the possibility to combine her skills with ours.On our way we get some side quests which lead us to different places, give us experience points and we find some useful items every now and then. There is also a dealer at different points where we can buy potions, ingredients and pieces of armor. During the main quest, we learn more about Dust's history and Dust in general, which gave me goosebumps several times. Furthermore, we can discover hidden arenas but at this point I won't mention what exactly is waiting for us in there.The graphics are comic-like and cute with small but fine animations and polyphonic music. This creates a good Atmosphere including dialogues between Dust and Fidget, which are very amusing most of the time. The differently designed areas provide variety. Not only our environment and the music changes, we also encounter new monsters with different and upgraded properties, where it is necessary to find out how we can beat them. The story was very touching and appealing. They did a great job with the combat system, its really fun especially when you run into 10-20 enemies at a time, you have the chance for long Hit-Combos, which give us more experience points.Overall, I liked playing Dust: An Elysian Tail very much.

I suppose I'd recommend this game, but it may not be some people's cup of tea.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												TL;DR: It's worth the price and moreso if it's on sale. Is a good way to get into several kinds of games. Also includes a concept called "FUN".[Length - average]: This game is too short. Depending on how much of a completionist you are- my playtime would have been 3 hours less if I hadn't gotten lost a couple times while looking in every nook and cranny to get to some of the hidden locations for the lost friends before giving in to frustration and googling it. I also don't think it has a lot of replay value.[Difficulty - good]: There's not much to say about this, you've got the casual, medium, hard and 1-Hit KO levels. I would say some of the platforming and the 6 Trials are a challenge regardless of which mode you set the game to though.[Combat - excellent]: Being a sword-wielding-furry-assassin with a cat-like-bat-thing that can shoot lightning and fire, in addition to lightbulbs, who can then do screen-clearing combo attacks is kind of awesome...[Music/Sound - good]: I couldn't hear the actual music most of the time because of all the exploding enemies and other sound effects but when I did hear it, it matched the surroundings perfectly. The sound effects are also spot on and paired with the music, proceeded to make this 25 year old freak the heck out in Sorrowing Meadow (I would recommend not letting your young children see the spiders or mansions). [Voice Acting - good]: All the voices were decent which is saying something considering I try to mute that feature most of the time because of how bad it is usually. Fidget's voice actor, especially, nailed it in cutscenes with emotions or humor and her interactions with Dust really made me like the little sidekick.[Graphics - excellent]: I love the artstyle which is simple yet detailed at the same time and allows for even toasters like mine to run it flawlessly...unless you turn on weather and bloom effects which ruins the art and your framerate simultaneously![Story/Characters - excellent]: The story is very short and straightforward for the most part. It's not bad though because it's told well and the characters are what really brings it to life. I would almost describe the game's plot as a prologue or origin story because of...[The Ending - good]: Other than feeling empty because you have to find something else to play now- It satisfies you by wrapping up the main point of the game while giving you the craving for a sequel it so kindly dangles above you.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												"Ashes to ashes...and dust to dust."Expertly and exquisitely crafted over the course of years in the mind of animation artist Dean Dodrill, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a 2D Metroidvania action-RPG that does just about everything right - and impressively at that. The amnesiac Dust and his irresistibly cute buddy Fidget trek across landscapes of forest, flame, shadow, and snow, combining and unleashing Dust's unparalleled swordplay skills with Fidget's dynamic magical projectiles in a furious typhoon of combat against a range of foes and obstacles - all part of a journey seeking answers to salient questions: who is Dust, really? - and is there still a time and a place for a hero to save the world?Each region traversed throughout Dust's 12-to-20-hour journey offers both platforming challenges to be navigated and mobs of monsters to be obliterated. Dust controls quite tightly, and all of his (and Fidget's) commands can be remapped as desired. Virtually all of the scenery in the world of Dust: AET is a rich delight, owing to its lush construction and ace visual design and demonstrating how gorgeous and appealing two-dimensional media can become. Also of note is the game's masterful soundtrack. Urgent strings, delicate pianos, and ambient synth pads are but a few of the pleasing instruments wonderfully woven into memorable melodies and soundscapes by Hyperduck Soundworks, working smoothly alongside Alexander Brandon (of Deus Ex fame). Rewarding side quests and imposing challenge arenas stand ready to be completed; fun cameos (by other indepedent game characters) and dozens of shout-outs to gaming and animation supply much-welcome joy between moments of surprisingly poignant sorrow. The game's cast is interesting, well-written, and voiced competently; consequent empathy with the hopeful villagers instills a resolve to aid their plight and answer their prayers. Each of the game's facets was created prudently and smartly - that it is an absolute blast to play seals the deal.All in all, Dust: AET is one of the most rewarding games I've played in a while. It is, to its end, stellar. Congratulations, Dean: you *nailed* this one.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I was disappointed a little bit in this game, but perhaps it is my fault. When I bought this game I thought it is a cute game. I knew it is not exactly or totally cute but I had not guessed what I will see.  Lets see my problems with this game first; My first weird feeling begun when 'Fidget' (the cute yellow Nimbat) is talking to the player (you). This threw me out of the story line. My second problem that only a few times at the beginning 'Dust' a little bit unreasonably rude with 'Fidget'. But after the beginning they will be fine. My third problem the world. This world a very cruel! Okay, I have already seen cruel things in game. But there are much more cruel what I expected! Many harmless people died there and you cannot help them. And at the end 'Everdawn Basin' when you destroy a plane and it feels down that kills your ally soldiers! I very dislike it, it is too much real! These my problems due I did not expect that much cruel.  The sheep, bunny and the deer are really cute. And the characters are likeable. And all these things have put into a cruel world and story.  So, if you guess it is a cute game, then please go deeper and check that what is waiting for you.   As the game it is good. The hand drawn characters at first look like too simple but I liked it. The game control, levels and crafts are simple, I could used to it easily. The English voice actors did a good job, every characters talking by empathy. I played with Gnu/Linux Xubuntu 64bit and there was only a few program errors over 68 hours playtime.  To the Achievement Hunters: Get all achievement difficulty: Normal  Good things: Likeable characters and cute sheep, bunny and deer. Good voice acting. Easy control.  Bad things: Too cruel story to a cute game. A few program errors over 68 hours playtime. At the beginning there are a few weird and unreasonably rude conversation.  I recommend this game to those who like the 2D playground, the hand drawn style view. I am not recommend this game to those who dislike the drama and cruel things with the likeable characters.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a Beautiful action adventure RPG 2D Hand-drawn and animated game. Whether you play for an absorbing story, exciting combat, or the joy of exploration, Dust has you covered. The main character Dust doesn't remember who he is. But he's teamed up with floating friend Fidget and wizened talking sword Ahrah. Together, the three of you travel the land of Falana, righting wrongs and uncovering the secrets of Dust's true identity. You gather new equipment and ability upgrades to slowly expand your movement possibilities, fight lots of enemies and bosses, help out others via side quests, and gather hidden treasure. Mixing and matching various attacks and combos is thrilling, and combined with the awesome animation, start flying back and forth while spamming magic attacks at bosses.There's great gameplay, graphics, music, and heart here, and I'm glad I picked it up on the steam sale. I would HIGHLY recommend getting this game!

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Upon completing the game in about 70 hours or so on its hardest difficually. It gave me a fair and just battle through the entire game. After going through countless waves upon waves of enemies, improving my abilities and skills therein I was overcoming obstacles left and right while upgrading my character to his peak conditions. Now a few things I gotta say for prase and complaints. 1. The game pulls off a very tough challenge in its battles where every boss or major enemy appears in a specific battle arena. You have to be observant while fighting these enemies and plan your means of attack. Esp. on the Toughest challenge mode. I cannot stress how satisfying this game is with how it brought out in battling hordes of enemies without slowdown at all!2. The Story is simple. Filled with rememberable characters. Though if I had to say a bit more with this short game it is all focused onto your main character. Nothing more. Sure you may do some side quest to help some of the worlds citizens to collect something here and there. But more or less it is fun and enjoyable experince.3. The time spent into this game is mostly grinding and Exploration because of my playthrough I was stupid (smart?) enough to play my first playthrough on the toughest setting. I died countless upon countless of times and over and over again I had to see the loading game screen. There are save panels applenty and with the right equips you can overcome any challenges. Just be sure to have the reflexes.4.At the end of the game I was engrossed in the world they developed. I haven't felt this way since well... Sonic the Hedgehog started development. There is always a hankering inside my mind that this isn't the end. No it is just the beginning of great things to come. If there was a prequal or a sequal to this game. My bet is that it will be day one purchase! Just make the game a bit more.....Substancial and more understanding. That is all! Props to the creators for this wonderful game!From Harvey Storm AKA Sleven

Posted: June 17, 2015
												Dust: An Elysian Tail... A Good Hack'n Slash Game made by the incredble creator,Dean Dodrill.The Guy who poured his heart and soul for this gem,The features and especially the bodies of the characters are well designed. Especially Dust in his combat stance,His attacks are fitting with the mouse buttons. The enemies are really fun to beat as you are using a sword called Ahrah who seems to know something about Dust's past. and Don't forget about our dear creature,Fidget. as You are using her projectile attack with Dust's DUST STORM attack. The Results are incredible. Especially when it comes to that annoying Exploding enemy. Strategy can be used when it comes to tight situations.I also got to see Super Meat Boy in the game,He is one of the friends that needs to be rescued as well as the others.The Bosses are good as well,The Voice Acting was amazing especially Dust,Fidget and Haley's.If you want to play a Metroidvania Hack'n Slash game,then this game should do the job. Notice that it's game filled with furries. I especially don't mind,as I also hate the furry fans but this game is just impossible to ignore. I am really happy to see this game in PC instead of just an XBOX game alone.. The combat and the voice acting are great.-Voice Acting 8/10-Combat 9/10-Enemies 8/10-Story 7/10Overall: 8.5/10 - AmazingMy Opinion: Get the game if you want hack and slash with metroidvania combined!

Posted: April 28, 2014
												This is a great labour of love. can't find anything bad about it, i just like it and the idea that essentially (mostly) one guy poured open his heart for years to deliver this awesome game.This game is that good designed that EVERY big publisher/developer can only burry his face in shame. The options menu is astonishing, the tools the game gives you to set up your game tell you: Yes, this is a PC game. A REAL PC GAME. But... its not. It came out on console first and the developer took the time to port it REALY GOOD instead of dumping it on the PC as it is usual buisness these days. I mean ... the game detects if you use gamepad or keyboard/mouse ON THE FLY AND CHANGES MENUS ACCORDING, prompts the correct buttons etc... you can scale your ui, set it up etc... for a "stupid little" single player ARPG? Wow. Only 2 little things are missing and 1 is kinda major...1) you can't rebind controller buttons (you can rebind mouse/keyboard)2) You can - as of now - not change the language ... that is realy bad, because the game orients itself on your system default language and to change it you either have to change your system language or go into your install dir (of the game) and delete (/rename) your language folder so the game defaults  to english ...this wont bother you once dealt with once but with such an astonishing optionsmenu its... strange to be missing :)the gameplay is solid and feels good. I like the dialogue / voiceacting but thats a matter of taste i guess, this game is no gore/bloody/badass-game so beware Mr/Mrs Cowadooty.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Yes, yes, yes yes! I loved this game!Like many others have said, combat is indeed boring - it's a very specific style, so unless you're a huge fan of it there isn't much you can do to like it better -, and considering you get to combat quite a lot in a game like this, I was expecting to NOT recommend it, but... everything else was so fiiiiine I didn't even get bored for having to smash the same button over and over. Seriously, look at the screenshots here in the Store. The background is so damn fine you can just keep looking at it forever if you get tired of looking at the monsters getting cut.Combat excluded, this game is flawless.Artwork is GORGEOUS, the way the back and fore grounds blend is beautiful, soundtrack is actually very thought of (for a game of slashing monsters), voice acting is pretty good, writing (dialogs, papers/letters you pick up, story) is amazingly well done (did I mention this was mostly made by a single dude?) and other game mechanics make it up for the combat.There's one point where you get to the snow and it was SO magical. The snow in the ground will "react" in several ways depending if you jumped, if you just walked, if a monster walked, if you moved to attack... This is just one of the little details that made me like this game so much.Also, there's this "extra", which makes you go around freeing your "friends", and at the map you free them, the game changes to copy that friend's game. Like, when you're freeing The Kid from Bastion, you have an empty map that is filled with ground when you walk around, just like in Bastion. Or when you're freeing the little guy from FEZ, your screen gets cut in like 9 pieces all out of place, so you don't know where you'll end up if you walk off the screen. These were great!

Posted: March 27, 2014
												Yes, yes, A thousand times yes.This, is easily my favourite game I've played in a long, long time, and one fo the first games I'm actually sad its over.When you considder this game was made by a single person, its outstanding how beautiful this game is. The art, the music, the gameplay, I can't fault it. The game is balanced well and eases you into the controls and skills you obtain along the way.I almost feel bad I got this from the humble bundle and didn't buy it full price. I said before that I regretted buying octodad at its current price due to lack of content and the fact you can complete it within 2-3 hours. This game is the same price and its taken me 16 hours to complete, and i still have yet to find all the treasure, secrets, side quests and fully level up. If you haven't played this game yet, get to it because you won't regret it.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												The game itself is alright, It could of used some more balancing though.Don't take this the wrong way, I have enjoyed the game and I'm still not finished playing it. I just wish I could disable the specified things below to add to the challenge of the game.- Dust Storm: Really this is the most unbalanced thing in the game. The ground attack itself is pretty helpful, But even that had the inability to protect you from behind. As a result enemies could still damage you, Which balances it out. But once you unlock the ability to use Dust Storm in the air, You're practically invincible. On top of this, It can enable you to skip areas and obstacles entirely by homing in on enemies above you, and being able to fly the to the top of the area. All you'd have to do then is find the exit.- Fidgits projectiles: All this really does is add to the already unbalanced Dust Storm, And make it even more ridiculous. This practically disables the balancing of the ground Dust Storm attack, by enabling you to attack enemies from behind. Now you're immortal on the ground. Use it in the air, And it's even-more-so. The aerial version of Dust Storm already enables you to deal massive damage to enemies whilst not taking any damage, Add in any of Fidgit's projectiles and you can quickly kill everything that moves, Including some bosses. Really it's possible to beat the entire game only using this tactic.Really these are the two major things, It's not worth listing the others. Aside from the issues I did enjoy the game very much, and I would recommend it to other people. I just wish we could alternate the controls and disable certain things.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												TLDR at the bottom.Before starting I want to say some things first:I am normally not a regular and great reviewer, but I felt this game really needs some positive feedback, also english is not my native language so bear with me please.I will try my best to describe the experience I had whilst playing this game.I will try to cover some story aspects first and the gameplay and graphics afterwards.At the end of the review I will rate the specific categories from 1-5 stars for each.Its really amazing what some people could establish with creating such a great game, I would like to thanks them for it.For the credibility of this review: I completed this game to 100%-whole story-all sidequests-all treasures-all achievementsReview - Dust: An Elysian TailDust: An Elysian Tail is a side scrolling combat game, it has the look and some - thank god - downgraded combat from Street Fighter 3/4.StoryThe story is heartwarming and very interesting. It never felt boring or long drawn out.You are starting as an unkown soldier who gets called "Dust".He is constantly trying to find an answer who he really is and soon he will realize that he will face a bigger threat than he actually thought of.As you progress you will remember more and more of the past and learn who you really are.Your cute, little flying companion called Fidget is  travelling beside you on the adventure, she is the gatekeeper of the sword.The sword that got awakend through your "hands" is called Ahrah and can talk to you. I would describe Ahrah has your mentor.The NPC' s in this game are all very unique. Each with its own dialogues and background story.By far the most interesting NPC is your companion Fidget imo. Her dialogues are funny and pretty well structured.The mainstory and the characters bound to the main story are well thought and I had a ton of fun doing and listening to the main story quests.While this game has a lot of funny dialogues and easter eggs it also has some really sad parts which made me sometimes cry.(Not sure if good or bad, lol)Dialogues:The dialogues are all unique and most of them are pretty funny. Some of them are sad.The element of sarcasm was used alot and.I really liked the voice acting in this game. It really felt "alive".Most of them are decent sized, but 10-20% are pretty large.Graphics:Its a cartoonish look with some really detailed combat animations. It really fits this genre and theme.Some of the environment changes as you use specific skills.Every area has its own climate.There are grassy, rainy, windy, snowy and dark areas.Not really much more to say.Combat/ Enemies:(I played this game from the beginning with a controller, never tested it with keyboard + mouse)The combat is pretty smooth and easy to learn. You are starting with only some bunch of sword attacks but as you progress you will get more and more useful combos and your companion also will gain new skills which you can combine  with yours while fighting.Pretty interesting is also the aspect that you can parry enemy attacks and counter them afterwards.As you progress - learn new skills - and master them, the game becomes more and more fun to play.At the beginning of your adventure the enemies are pretty weak and not a big threat. But as you progress through the game and discover new areas, the enemies will get stronger and stronger.Some of the enemies you will encounter are dodging and require some decent tactics.Progression:After every level up you gain 1 skill point. There is not an in depth skill tree.You can choose between 4 attributes. (HP, Damage, Defense and Skillpower)I dont really think an in depth skill tree would make sense at this game. It would only complicate and slow down the action oriented gameplay imo.All in all you gain level quite quick. Pretty fast leveling until ~40ish.Equipment/ Crafting:After some 2-3 hours into the game you will get to a blacksmith.In exchange for the blueprints and the materials you will get some really good equipment.There is a weapon slots, armor slots, 2 rings and 1 amulet slot.The equipment is not visible as you change it.You dont have to farm for materials.If you collect a specific material one, and sell this to a vendor, the vendor starts selling this specific material in the future.All in all the equipment and crafting is pretty simple.Sound:While the game was developed by 1 person, the sound actually came from a specific sound studio.Every map has its own sound and music.In most of the games I played, the sound got pretty boring after a while and I switched to some own background music.In my 15-20 hours of gameplay the sound and the music never got on my nerves.Sidequests:There are like ~20 sidequests beside the main story which you can optionally complete. They will grant you Exp/ Gold and sometimes items.At most of them you have to collect items, kill monsters or find some lost NPC's.Good thing is: You will complete most of them by actually following the main quest.Puzzles:Every map contains some puzzles or hidden treasures. Some of them are easter eggs from other games.After you enter a new map which contains a treasure, your companion Fidget will tell you that.Your minimap will also tell you if you collected all treasures of a map.A circle on the map means that you have treasures left to collect, a dot means that you collected all treasures of that map part.Most of them are easy to find and simple to unlock.Instances/ mini gamesThere are 6 instances called "Cirelian Trials", you will stumble across them while progressing through the game.The are a great help at keeping the gameplay fresh.They are basically a mix of jumping puzzles and speedrunning through a specific area.You have to make it through the whole trial in time, without getting hit by the traps and beside that you have to destory some sort of "candle bearer" to get points.After you completed a trial you will most of the time get really good equipment parts.Personal rating:Story: 5/5Graphics: 4/5Dialogues: 4/5Combat/Enemies: 5/5Progression: 4/5Crafting/ Equipment: 4/5Sound: 5/5Sidequests: 3/5Puzzles: 3/5Instances/ mini games: 4/5TL:DRI give this game a 4-5 out of 5.I had a blast playing this game, its much more worth as its actual prize.While playing I really felt the passion and the hard work dedicated to the creating of this game.Triple A games can really learn something from this game.Controller essential imo.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												Phew... It's everything but easy to write a review to this game.To be honest, if this game had been published from a major company, I might have been disappointed. But it is an Indie-Game (and the first one Noogy ever made), so naturally one cannot compare it to a major release.All in all it is a really great game, hands down. ;)Now enough talk, let's get to the likes and dislikes.Likes:absolutely gorgeous artwork and animationsan overwhelming soundtracksmooth and action oriented gameplaygreat voice actingan absolutely cute and funny sidekickfunny innoendos about video game oddities (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)unintrusive and funny 4th wall breaksnice refferences to other games  (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)perhaps not innovative but nevertheless interesting aproach on crafting and trading (increasing the trader's assortment by selling new items to them)the Mysterious Wall Chicken!Dislikes:level grinding and item/gold farming is way too easyFidget becomes way too overpowered (I stopped using her powers at the meadows to keep the game halfway challenging, although I cranked up the difficulty before)speaking of challenge: the first and the last boss fights were the only ones which were challenging to me, the latter perhaps only because I didn't use fidgetevery health item stronger than the Mysterious Wall Chicken! is a bad bargain to buy (using 2 chickens heals 160 hp for 600 coins, the hot cocoa heals 160 hp for 640 coins, the birthday cake has an even worse cost-benefit ratio, so you end up swallowing countless chickens because it is the cheapest way to heal - but Mysterious Wall Chicken FTW!, so why should I care? :D )About the story... well, I'm actually a bit torn appart about it.Yes, it follows quite common tropes and is per se not that innovative, but it IS a good story and keeps you interested, if you alow yourself to delve into it.But there are two major drawbacks about the story. The first and the most disappointing is that major plot elements are revealed waaaaaayyyy too early. In Aurora Ginger tells you that you're dressed like a royal assassin - first half of the plot revealed, and shortly after someone tells you about a "twin soul" - not sure if Fuse allready talks about it, but Lady Tethys most certainly does and thus revealing the other half of the plot.So roughly after the first third of the game you can allready figure out what is going on, only the "when, where and why" is kept a secret until the near end.The second drawback about the Story is that "it seems to be a bit shallow". That's one thing often critizised at negative reviews about Dust. Well, i dare to disagree, hence the quotation marks.I think the story itself is not that shallow (at least not more shallow than the Halo-Storyline *duck and cover*), but it is told in a shallow fashion. The arcs of suspense are boiled down to short cutscenes with only a few lines of dialouge and major plot twists are given away early and in a way as if they were only a negligibility.So I say the Story would gain more positive reviews if it was told in a different way and revealed in a "different order".Well, yes, this was quite a bit of a breakdown, pointing out more negative features than positive ones.But: Every positive feature mentioned outweights the negative ones by far.It is an absolutely great game and mindblowingly detailed - especially if you take into consideration that this is the first game ever released by Noogy. Thats why I give this Game a thumbs up - I absolutely love it!Oh and in case you haven't noticed yet: I friggin' LOVE the mysterious wall chicken !!! :D

Posted: May 25, 2013
												Imagine Castlevania, mashed with Metroid, topped with RPG mechanics, throw in a beautiful art style and stir well. That is Dust: An Elysian Tail. If you liked Castlevania or Metroids gameplay (the classics, not the primes or...whatever the hell the last castlevania was) you'll probably love this game's feel. It's got a neat hack n' slash combo type fighting system that progresses fairly well with new abilities coming in at just the right time. The only downside is the game is a tad easy. Still, this game is nearly perfect in every category with a whomping roughly 14 hours of gameplay + time to get the rest of the achievements. For a 15 dollar game, it was more than satisfying. I liked the story, some people didn't feel the same way, some of the characters are annoying but they'll grow on you. And of course, people who hate furries will probably want to stay away from this game despite it being fantastic, since wutwill/b/think. Anyhow, for the price, gotta give this a 9.8/10. Must buy for old school MetroidVania fans.

Posted: May 18, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing game, probably one of the best games I have ever played. Lets get started then! The gameplay is AMAZING. The fighting system makes you feel powerful and is easy to get the hang of, but enemies can be pretty intelegent and hit hard to balance it out. Dust may be a hard game but it's also fair, if you get hit you have nobody to blame but yourself. Controles are responcave, but I have to wounder why the are optimized for left handed people. Nothing against left handed people, it's just right-handedness is far more common. Not that this subtracts from anything. 10/10 for gameplay.  Level design is good. You are never really bafeled on what to do next.  The first half half the the game has really fun level design, but it starts going downhill on chapter 3, the last part of the game is pretty good though. Enemies, while fun to fight, should have had a little more veriety, especially during the last 2 chapters. Most of the bosses merly meet the stadards they have, but the final boss is increadably good. Overall I give the level disign a 8/10 Music is... Meh. While the all music is very pretty, there are only two memorable songs; the song for the last stretch before the final boss, and the final boss's song. 7/10 The art is... Wow. Just wow. The art style is wounderful, and each sprite looks like it was hand-painted. Easilly the having the best grafics I have ever seen in a videogame, Dust is the only game where I can honastly say the grafics increased my enjoyment. Plus, there is a mode for colorblind people to deal with the few spots in the game where you need to see color. 10/10 for art. And now for the story. Which is great. Dust is one of the few games that got me to care about the story. The ending subratcs a little though. (SPOILER ALART!)  You die at the end. OK, I can see that sacrifice as being nessisary. But then you might not be dead? After burning in lava? Really? (END SPOILER ALART!) 9 out of 10 for story.Well that wraps that up. I would EASILY recomend this game. It's a little short, so if you get it try to do all the sidequests. Luckily multiple diffaculty settings triple the replayability. (Just don't do casual. Casual mode is for wimps. You can't die in that mode.) 8/10 overall.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Moderately fun side scrolling hack and slash plat forming RPG game. Played on the second hardest difficulty with a usb playstation controller and it took about 10 hours to beat it just doing the main quest line. About 2 hours of that was just grinding because I didn’t bother with the crafting system so my gear wasn’t that good. The enemies are not that difficult until you get to the last area. The greatest challenge came from the platforming as jumps were often very difficult to make. Your regular jump often does not reach high enough so you have to attack in mid air to get that extra height boost, but this makes sticking your landing in the right spot more difficult. You also often just randomly fall through platforms when you land on them which can be frustrating. I also had to restart the game on several occasions because I would just randomly fall through and get stuck inside of walls. The good thing is there are a lot of save points so even if you get stuck you don't have to restart that far back. The story line/dialog is kind of cringey, but I just skipped most of it. The environment looks pretty nice, but sometimes it is hard to tell what you can jump on or what hurts you as the background and foreground kind of blend in with the main area at times. I wouldn’t recommend buying this game at full price, but since it was included in the humble bundle 11 you can probably get it for cheap.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Picked this game up on the recommendation of a few friends; have to say it was worth it. The graphics look stunning for a game made almost entirely by one person. The colors are very vibrant and really accentuate the atmosphere the rest of the game provides. The combat is very fluid, and it is quite entertaining using fidget powers with the dust storm flinging projectiles around the screen. Dust is littered with RPG elements from leveling up certain attributes to finding and crafting new equipable items (though his character sprite never changes). The story that unfolds as you proceed through the game is truly the icing on the cake which I will not spoil.However, Dust does suffer from its share of short comings. The replay value is not there, atleast from a new game file there isnt. You can collect all the items and most of the achivements in a single playthrough. The voice acting is mediocre and can sometimes be a little annoying (looking at you fidget..), but in the same breath has its moments. Overall I would rate this game an 7.5/10, and only because its a one shot wonder. So buy it on sale and enjoy!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												The game overall is good, story is interesting, visuals are really pretty, and the combat is dynamic.However, as much as I like it, i can't help but be irritated by some parts of it.Note, that partially it comes from playing on hardcore (highest) difficulty.In multiple places things like jumps and drops (especially while climbing on vines), need to be done almost pixel-perfectly. I guess you could ignore that if you can simply retry, but a problem arises if when you fail, you end up on spikes or some other damage-inducing crap.Also, on vines you just never know how exactly will Dust jump, which in many cases means spikes to the face..Undeniably the most irritating part of the game for me was a piece of Cirromon Caverns around the middle bottom of the map.It consists of 2 tunnels filled with spikes that you have to jump over, with mushrooms between them, that spill damaging particles. The thing is, that these mushrooms work completely randomly, and they give you effectively no warning - technically they flash around 0.5s before they do something, but it barely gives you time to dodge- oh wait, i forgot that YOU'RE SURROUNDED WITH SPIKES SO YOU CAN'T EVEN DODGE. And there goes half of your hp.So there's no way to predict that they're gonna produce these particles, it's hard to dodge them, and even if you do, you end up on spikes. Of course, they're technically a part of the background, so you can't even 'kill' them.While it's not impossible, it's close to being it, if you need/want to do it while not getting hit even once. You just need luck, lots of it.Oh, for some reason, if you take damage by touching the fire, you bounce back few meters as if you took a ♥♥♥♥ing sledgehammer to the face. Yeah.When it comes to enemies, there are 2 that are a real pain:Demons, who will flank the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you and instakill you from behind (yeah sure, you can dodge, right? but only so much, and then you die). Sometimes they will also jump on you with a spinning attack and kill you before you notice them. Thanks for great camerawork, game.Necromancers, which you can damage only with Fidget's projectiles that use up energy, which is also used to dodge Explosive Zombies spawned right in your face by these Necromancers, that explode after 0.5s and instakill you..This is some bad level design.Don't play on hardcore, kids.

Posted: September 16, 2015
												Great 2D fighter. Story is amazing and captivating, while the characters are intriguing and likeable. Combat feels good, and the lack of combos is made up for by how easily you can string special moves together. Voice acting has its charms, and grows on you over time. 9/10

Posted: February 15, 2014
												with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..the combat.ohhhh the combat.MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.IT IS PERFECT.there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

Posted: May 22, 2015
												A simple 15-20 hr side-scrolling action game. A Metroidvania with anthros.tl;dr review:Play it but mute the voice. Longer full review below.I initially bought it mostly because I heard it was made by one guy, and the fact I love metroid games. Well technically, this game is made by one guy + a bunch of voice actors, but it really should have been made by one guy and no voice actors. More on that later. I was rather curious seeing how a single guy could write, programme, draw/animate a game all by himself. In terms of combat and enemy variety and overall gameplay, I say this game is pretty great in that department. Dust: An Elysian tail gives you basic sword attacks like a simple side-scrolling action game, but it includes some Devil May Cry-like combos including the ability to launch enemies a helm breaker style attack an a parry system similar to like in Metal Gear Rising using holding the light attack while facing your enemy at the correct timing. The defining characteristic of the combat system is the dust storm, where dust spins his sword wildly that when combined by his little friend Fidget's elemental attacks results in a giant storm of elemental fury, projectiles flying everywhere, chain lightning, pillars of flame. My only complain is that there are only three elements, not a lot of variety there.The difficulty of the game is weird though. RPGs always come in three forms, either they start really easy and become insanely difficult in the end, forcing you to grind, or, you start hard and end the game steam rolling everything even the boss (Oh Skyrim is the biggest culprit of this). This game contains RPG levelling and one that makes the difficulty that goes easy>hard>easy. The final boss was more of an endurance run rather than an actual challenge with 4 phases which is... too long. You might say he's the final boss, it should be long, yes, but it also wasn't challenging, so I was basically waiting to win and wasn't anywhere near death or in need to use a healing item (which the game generously drops a bunch). With the large amount of enemies you fight leading up to the final boss, you're gonna overlevel, and that certainly did not help. Still, besides the final boss, the first three bosses, when you aren't actually overleveled, did in fact gave me a challenge. Thus so this is another one of those games where the final boss ends up being easier than the first. But no matter, the other bosses had clever patterns and were a decent enough challenge so I'll let that easy final boss part go and give this gameplay a 9.Combat and Gameplay 9/10Story is.... ehhh. Of course it's not Lord of the Rings, I'm not expecting an epic story, but well, forget it. The gameplay alone is good, just don't bother with the story, it's not important nor a deciding factor of buying this game.Story - whatever/10Level Design is an important thing in a metroidvania game, and overall I did not feel that this game had a very good level design. It's really straightforward, so much so it's kinda boring. The world is put together with an overworld map connecting everything, and if you ever played Castlevania: Order of Ecclessia and found how straightforward and boring the levels are, well there you go. There's not a lot of branching paths and most of the secrets are just so obvious I wouldn't even call it a secret anyway. Remember that feeling when you first broke the glass with a power bomb in super metroid? or when you discovered the area where the rain mysteriously stopping in mid air is actually an invisible floating platform? Of course, I'm not saying the game is just a straight line every level, neither was Castlevania: OoE. All I'm saying is, this game didn't give me any real sense of discovery like when I'm walking through Dracula's castle in SotN. Many of the collectibles are just in too obvious locations.On the other hand, the game does have some interesting platforming sections. Some good some bad. They're not the Tower of death level of difficulty or cleverness with moving platforms, spinning blades, spikes and medusa heads of course, but it is a good enough challenge in their own right.Level design - 7/10Sound, music is good, lots of catchy tunes but the problem is.... the voice acting... oh no... Nooo.. Just nooo............ This is why this one man game... should have remained a one man game. The voice acting is anywhere from acceptable to just plain awful. And I'm not talking about Fidget which many other reviewers seem to hate. For me, Fidget (and Dust actually) sound okay. But Ginger is bad. She's suppose to be sad and depressed as the story claims, except every time she talks, she sounds indifferent, like a robot, not giving a damn, even when a certain character supposedly died at the end, she was like "oh no what do I do....??". Like I said, the music, is pretty good. The voice acting? NOPE, NOPE, NOPE.Overall 8/10. A solid side scrolling action game. The Combat is awesome, the enemies and bosses are really clever. The dust storm mechanics just makes fighting in this game fun as hell. The only real downside of this game is the voice acting, and that's it.

												Oh my god this game is a masterpiece beyond belief. This kind of metroidvania gameplay is phenomenal and so loose-flowing with the controls. Fighting is at it's smoothest with the amounts of combos and other dangerous attacks Dust has at his disposal. The story's solid, and it goes through a lot of different forms of losses that most games capture most of the time, but not at a scale like this. I only have a few problems currently. Dialogue does tend to drag on a bit, though it's a very minor nitpick and skipping it is an option. The difficulty in all four modes aren't really present unless you're playing on the hardest difficulty, but even then all the handed items (like wall chicken) makes that mode easy. Lastly, the leveling gap in the final area is very obvious to note. Even without grinding to cap and getting good items, it felt like something was missing.Hopefully the development team makes a sequel to this game. It was by far my most favorite in 2013!

Posted: February 8, 2014
												A very fun game, though not a particularly challenging one.Combat is very responsive and flows nicely; almost too nicely since you'll very rarely get hit. I would recommend playing the game on Hardcore difficulty so its at least a little challenging at the start, though it quickly becomes a cake walk anyways once you level up a bit. Later on in the game, after you've torn through thousands of basic enemies, some more interesting enemies start showing up, such as one that can only be hurt by projectile attacks and one that can mimic your aerial dust storm ability. Unfortunately, by that point, you're so ludicrously overpowered, that it doesn't matter, even on hardcore difficulty.But while it's a very easy game, its also a very fun one. You can impale enemies, launch then into the air, then turn into a tornado of slashing chaos and launch into the air before sending the poor creature back down to earth. And then you zap everyone on the screen with lightning.So if you're looking for a challenging game to test your skill against, look somewhere else; but if you just want to pass the time with some fun hack'n'slash action against hordes of hapless opponents, you could certainly do a lot worse than this. And that's really the whole point of video games, isn't it: FUN.

Posted: March 28, 2014
												Have no fear, this game is completly abstinent! But I think that's to be expected from a game rated E 10+!Dust is an action, platforming, RPG. The sole mechanic is the "Dust Storm", a special move that lets you glide through the air and attack enemies. This move assists in combat as well as platforming.The game's level design is split up so that you are platforming half the time, and the other half you are mowing down bad guys. It is unfortunate that there are only two distinct moments when you are doing both at the same time, and I would have appreciated more moments that combined combat and platforming.Many areas are blocked off at the beginning of the game until you unlock the special ability that lets bypass the specific obstacle blocking your way. These blocked off areas don't conceal anything super special, but I find a lot of joy exploring the map trying to find all the hidden chests.The story is well written and well executed, and kept me engaged the entire time. There were certain sad moments that didn't effect me that much, but the chills I got at the cutscene before the final boss made up for that! There were countless jokes thrown in along the way that made me laugh!Overall, I think the game was a pleasent expierence and I would strongly recommend it!

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Just.... WOOOOOW!Dust: An Elysian Tail is a side-scrolling hack'n'slash game, and for me, an awesome one.First of all, the graphics: they are just purely beautiful and colorful, the quality of design (maps/player/enemies) is perfectly looking like a drawn picture or anime/cartoon and nothing is ♥♥♥♥ed. Each detail is cured very nicely (foreground same as background and everywhere else on screen) and levels are all nice, even thou' they are all different (rain, snow, villages,...)Now, the controls: they are easy to understand and handling is really fast (keyboard+mouse same as controller). Action time is not boring after some hours passed on it.Lets talk about the music now: and it is great point of the game. its music and ambiant sounds are clean and perfect. You play with a quiet and magnificent music, zen and close to lyrical register. Ambiant sounds (rain, thunder,...) are very realistic. And the last point, the story: Story looks great, characters are attractive and beautiful and Dust (the main one)more than anyone else, 'cause he does not know his past... What will happen?Of course, there is a good humor in it (and also some litlle bad words :P) but you will appreciate close to all characters (except that Gianni, I still got problems to like him after the first met).Conclusion:[/b][/i]In other words. This is one of my new favorite games! A real love at first sight (and play if I can say like that ^^').Really, I recommand that game if you like scrolling games with anime/cartoon animations. It is a very delighting game, a true pearl for eyes and you can just stay on levels just for hearing the music.Then, if you play at it, just ENJOY IT! ;)

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is one of those argument-ending 'Name one' games."Games aren't artistic! Name one!""PC ports are impossible, and they'll always be faulty. Name one that wasn't!""Actio brawlers can't have major plot twists! Name one!""Comic relief sidekicks are such a pain. Name one time that they did that right."Well... this is that kind of game, yes. The controls are smooth, the voice acting is gorgeous, the soundtrack deserves to be called 'epic,' even the scenery is chewing the scenery, and as for the story? It's the kind of story where you think you know what the twist is going to be early on, but then they throw a curve ball at you and do something pretty unexpected, even unique. All three of the main characters (yes, the sword is a character) are at least interesting, Fidget is downright brilliant on so many levels, and even the shopkeeper has a story. Yeah, not even kidding. The freaking SHOPKEEPER has a story, and it's not even a bad one. Probably best played with a controller, because there were instances where I struggled because I forgot you could jump diagonally by holding two keys at once (eheh...) but perfectly serviceable with mouse and keyboard, and its options menu is spot-on. There are features that you wouldn't think even existed. This game is a classic. It's iconic. And the controls are simple enough for someone new to games to pick up. Basically, in the spirit of the season, it's a good game for gamers and it's a good experience for non-gamers. All the beauty and heart of a Disney classic mixed with the action of a Nintendo classic. Definitely worth a look.

Posted: July 30, 2013
												One may see it as just a game made for furries. In truth, I don't see it that way. This game just goes beyond to what any other game today is. The animation is certainly amazing to see and the characters are wonderful. The story is just superb in its own way and it will surprise you many times. Thankfully the hero is not your typical type of "saving everyone's life" no matter what. It shows the emotion when the character fails to save a life and that is rare in a game these days. The music is sheer beauty. Maybe its because my favorite instrument is the piano but honestly its nothing short of awesomeness and will be with you till the very end. I highly recommend this game not because its a furry game, but because the story will surprise you.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Quite the charming game, the amount of love and care that has gone into its production is evident from the off. Behind the very impressive graphical schmaltz is where the true beauty of the game lies, though. The controls are fluid and very responsive, the storyline is surprisingly engaging and many of the characters, even the bit-part players, are extraordinarily likable. Others you'd quite like to kick through a wall but the game sadly doesn't give you that option.In short, a side-scrolling adventure platformer perfect for fans of such titles (think Metroid, Castlevania etc.) younger players and, er, furries.

Posted: August 11, 2015
												Ok, so when I first saw this game, I thought, "Oh, cool, a side-scrolling RPG with furries!"About 3 hours in, however, I slowly realized that this game is much, much more.When they said this game is "story-rich", I never knew what they meant until I played it for a bit. This game is really story-rich. You play as a cat/fox/thing named Dust, who  was once a solider of a currupt general name Giuss., who lost his memory, and is a accompanied by a bat/cat/Nimbat/thing called Fidget, and a talking sword name Ahrah.I can't really explain further. You just have to play the game to understand. So, seriously, buy it.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												Strikes a perfect balance between providing the backtracking and exploration the Metroidvania genre is known for and maintaing a constant sense of knowing what you need to do. Recommended to anyone with even a passing interest in the genre. Pros:-Fantastic visual design-Great writing-Clear, yet interesting level and quest design-Tons of secrets and optional quests, many of which aren't completable when you first get to them-Impressive enemy variety prevents using the same combat tactics for too long-Voice acting for the main cast is very well doneCons:-Several minor characters are poorly acted. They're not awful, but there's a noticeable drop in quality between them and Dust/Fidget in conversation.-Although the way you approach combat has to change throughout the game, mashing left click is generally all you need from the combo system, at least on Normal. Other:-It took me about 9 hours to finish Normal with around 70% completing. Going for 100% would probably take another 4 hours, and I'd expect higher difficulties to add to that significantly. -Some of Fidget's abilities can utterly destroy the balance of the game if you go all out for them. This may not be true on higher difficulties, and it's your choice to use them in combat regardless. -I was disappointed that only one quest had a branching ending and that, (MINOR SPOILERS) (EXTRA WARNING SPACE) although the villain's dialogue is written in a tone that implied he wasn't totally evil, his actions are never justified as anything other than genocide. (END SPOILERS) I don't consider either of these a con since it's expected from this genre, but it is missed potential.

Posted: February 18
												This game is superb. If you are looking for a great indie 2D action platformer, this is a game to get. The game mixes level-by-level gameplay of older side scrolling games with secret hunting and exploration of a metroidvania.  Fuse that with a combo system that actively rewards the player with bonus XP for playing skillfully and you have one amazingly fun action-platform-metroidvania-brawler-whatever-it-is-but-who-cares-it's-great. The first thing that will hit you is the amazing hand-drawn art and animations. This is an absolutely beautiful game to behold. The voice acting is a bit spotty at times but overall, well executed. The bomb sprout puzzles are a bit tedious but so satisfying when you solve them, bosses were way too easy but still fun none the less, some of the diolague can be excized as it outright tells you a puzzle solution, but it doesn't handhold so often that it becomes patronizing, and the ester eggs are just adorable. I haven't found half of the secrets this game holds, so there's still a lot of stuff left for me to do. But, I did complete the story; I will not spoil the ending but I will say it is an ending that leaves lots of mixed emotions, but in a good way. TL;DR the game isn't perfect, but no game is. This is the most fun I had in a 2D game since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. Some nitpicks here and there but those could be attributed to the fact that the development team was one person, and a multi-man team could have made more mistakes than fixed them. Overall, this game is a 9/10, one of my favorites, and it definately deserves the overwhelmingly positive reception it gets.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												This game is beautiful to a fault and the story is magnificent. I enjoyed every hour. Though it may be a bit of a 'slash em up' 2D side scroller, it has a difficulty level to suit all players, veterans and even less active gamers like myself.I give Dust: An Elysian Tail 10/10

Posted: December 30, 2013
												I'm not a fan of sidescrollers. I'm also not a fan of furries. This game has both of those things, though I can say without a doubt that it's the best purchase I've made so far on Steam. The art is beautiful, the voice acting is acceptable, the controls are solid(yes, even with a mouse and keyboard), and the gameplay is spectacular.If you missed out on this whilt it was ~$4, get it anyway. I would definitely pay full price. This game is a masterpiece, and everyone should give it a chance :)

The story at the end does kinda feel rushed and might've needed to have 2 of Gaius' men for bosses to even out the pacing.All in all easily a 8.5/10 on the worst of days, which for an indie dev with only 1 guy is astonishing and I hoep to here more from him and this world he created with the other 4 blades!

Dust has voice acting throughout, for the main character, and every other character you meet, which really aids the immersion in the world.The combat is fun and exciting, and even though it teaches you most of what to do, there are little quirks that you need to discover on your own as well.The story (what I've played through so far) is interesting, and makes me want to find out what happens next.PLAY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												11/10 Bashed a rock column with a talking sword and a prestine, fully cooked, ready to eat, roasted chicken fell out when it finally crumbled. Review is edited because this one wouldn't actually post:But in all seriousness...I bought this game for the Xbox360 when it first released, when I had heard it was released for the PC, I didn't hesitate to buy it again, at the full price. Yep, this game was valuable enough to me to BUY IT TWICE.How this game, made by ONE person specifically for the Xbox360, gets a better PC port than most Triple A titles just goes to show the lack-luster effort devs with literally hundreds of millions of dollars at their disposal throw at trying to satisfy their customers. One guy was able to do it better than an entire team of hundreds of people.This calls back to a time when games were made by gamers, for gamers - for enjoyment. Not by Publishers, for money - because f**k you. The game basically sells itself.People look at cliches with a stigma of "It's bad" when really most stories are just variations of the "Seven Basic Plot Points". Without revealing too much you've got: Generally quiet, withdrawn protagonist with memory loss, with the comedic relief side-kick and a literal facist antagonist. If you haven't stopped reading this review by now, buy the game dammit.As for the Genre, it's a heavy mix of Side-Scroller, Beat'Em Up, with some RPG leveling aspects in the background. This is a game you play for the gameplay and the story, not the genre itself, of which Dust: An Elysian Tale can't really figure out which category it's in.Speaking of gameplay, it's more akin to well, Halo's difficulty curve - veteran Halo players will know that Legendary isn't that difficult once you figure out the technique. Enemies hit hard, and have more health the further you push it up. So people looking to be an unstoppable force should start the game on Normal, it's easy enough. The biggest jump between difficulties is that Checkpoints regenerate less and less health the harder the difficulty. 100, 50, 25, and 10 percent respectively from Easiest to Hardest. Once you find an item that regenerates your health, you just go AFK and wait for Dust to heal while you grab a snack or something. I mean you could use all that food you've collected/bought - but why would you? Gotta save that resource, of which you have no limit to the number of items you can hold, all the way to the end of the, by which time you've beaten it and went through like all 14 hours of the game without eating a damn thing while, considering the moves you can pull off, Dust has to be burning like 10000 calories an hour here.Infact, that's probably my one critique, having to handicap yourself to make the game more difficult, even on the hardest difficulty. "BUT REACH IT SAYS YOU HAVEN'T BEAT THE GAME ON TOUGH OR HARDCORE." You got me skippy, I haven't... it's one of the few games for the Xbox360 I have to be completely finished for all achievements, back when it was released.Other things I should probably address:-"REACH, I SEE ANTHROS IN THE TRAILER AND THUMBNAILS UP ABOVE." It's the art style, honestly, I think anthropomorphic characters suit the design and direction better anyway. Pay no attention to it, the characters, save the talking sword, talk mostly normal save a few monologues. This isn't some spat-up Tumblr/Deviantart Anthro R34 garbage. Just by playing the game you can see the time and effort the creator dumped into making this game.-"Reach, why are you posting this review so late in the day if you bought it all the way back when?" I rarely post steam reviews, and only for game I consider to be extraordinary. This was on the front page because of the Steam Summer Sale, 2016 and I went "Huh, I should post a review on that, it's a good game."Ending notes:-Buy it-It's awesome-Lots of fun-Good story-Great gameplay-Feel the effort put into the game-Find all the goodies and extrasFinal thoughts: Didn't get poisioned at all on my first run through of the game. Second play through got over confident and finally got poisoned. Found out there was dialogue for being poisoned the first time. Purposely get poisoned first chance I get for the dialogue. 9/10 missed opportunity first time around.Talking sword said I shouldn't cause an avalanche. Flying nimbat said it was the only way to climb further up the mountain. Protagonist agrees with flying nimbat, not the sword he uses. 8/10 would tell Arrah to f**k off agian.Mouse guy named Avgustin is totally Canadian no matter what anyone says. 10/10 best game ever, most accurate portrayal of a Canadian.Game has hologram projectors to talk to a black smith that can somehow transport materials I'm carrying with me, along with money to the Blacksmith at the top of a huge hill and send them back to me whereever I am. Still only have a sword as a weapon. 7/10 want my Shotgun for fighting zombies.I bashed a metal flying aircraft with a sword, hooked it by the tip and slammed it into the ground. 10/10 MGS Revengence ain't got♥♥♥♥♥♥on Dust: An Elysian Tale.Wet suit has better defense stat than a Chain Mail vest. 3/10 no realism.

Posted: March 8, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is visually stunning, the writing is excellent, and the control system's responsive. The world and the characters in it are unique and interesting. Voice acting's versatile and brilliant. Gameplay wise, the difficulty is perfect. The enemies are not invincible, but are by no means are cakewalk either. As in any good combat-heavy game, the combat system is simple, but flexible. I've heard many people say that the bosses in this game are too easy, but I still find them challenging enough. I don't think Dust: An Elysian Tail intended that the bosses be particularly difficult; I think they intended for bosses to be links in the story and chances to show off their brilliant game - and level design. For those who find bosses too easy, or just want a more intense expirience, you can always up the difficulty level. Magic spam is a viable strategy in this game, but in order to pull it off you need to focus 100% of the time. Personally, I don't think it's a problem, nothing in this game is broken or unbeatable. All in all, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a diamond, and a valuable diamond to be precise. This game is in my list of top 10 games ever made, and I would recommend it to anyone who is even somewhat interested in getting it.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												My apology for not writing a review for this amazing game in the past, for some reason it escaped me.I just noticed the game is on sale 5/24/2014 and I STRONGLY recommend it even at full price. JUMP on this now, if you already haven't been blessed by getting to own and play this spectacular experience.  It pulls off amazing combat with cool abilities to string attacks together, you'll feel like you are flying through the air a.k.a. "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon" combat style...and while this happens you will enjoy beautiful music and graphics that are top notch...imagine Disney/Pixar quality in the best way.  Some people will tell you that this is an Xbox port but I believe that the author has stated that this game was originally written  on the PC.  I personally prefer to use a controller to play but it works with mouse and keyboard.  There is a lot to this game and you can go back and discover things that your character wasn't previously powerful enough to handle.  Combat is so fun repeating some areas does NOT feel grindy or boring at all.  Its hard to say that this is "the best platformer on the pc" because its so much more than just a platformer.  You really need to experience the amazing and fluid brawler/combat...Although button mashing will get you a little ways, you really need to have finesse when you play.  Adorable characters, amazing story...I hate to give things a numerical rating but in this case I'll give it 99 out of 100.  There is a LOT to this game and plenty of gameplay...the only reason I didn't give it 100 is I don't know if there will ever be that absolutely perfect game but this one is a razor's edge close to it. Once again--do yourself the favor of buying this game.  Encourage the developer to bring us more fantastic games.Not sure on this:  This game was somehow written by ONE person (and I believe he hired people to do voiceovers and music) but not certain.<3 Dust An Elysian Tail <3

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Gameplaywise, it's straightforward : you have one sword and learn several moves throughout the game. I thought this would limit the gameplay, making it boring at some point, but it didn't. The game is relatively short if you decide to do the campaign only, and becomes longer if you decide to do the subquest. You can find equipment to upgrade your sword & be more competitive in fights. The game itself is really easy, if you wish for a challenge, directly jump to the hardcore difficulty, where you really die easily if you gets hit (my advice : don't try to speedrun it, use combos & dodge as much as possible).Graphically : it's a cel-shaded style plat-former, who really take inspiration into Don Bluth's An American Tail animated movie in terms of artstyle (they even made the same pun). At first I thought it would be a problem since I'm really not a fan of the furry genre (due to what the Internet did to it, mostly) but it really only took inspiration in the Don Bluth movie style and never try to sexualize the characters like you can see many games do whenever they try to add androgynous animal characters. So yeah, I really felt I was watching an old animated movie, with the same kind of message Don Bluth himself would be able to convey (about war, destruction of nature, etc...)The story is cute, it's nothing great but it's very cute, very well acted, and I appreciate the voice actors' effort in the play.One big plus for this game is the music : the music is absolutely fantastic, and one of my favourite soundtrack in videogame's history. Not even kidding.It's charming, it's fun, it's pretty. The music is beautiful.It is a wonderful tail... I mean tale.

Posted: May 27, 2014
												6/10Overall I enjoyed this game. It's fun, the artwork is beautiful, and the story really comes together in surprising ways at the end.But there are a few complaints.The big one is the health system. When you level up, you can choose to upgrade your choice of four things, one of them being max health. There is virtually no point in upgrading your maximum health. There is no natural health regeneration, and there are no inns or any other sort of place that you can go to restore your health. Completing a level does not heal you. The ONLY way is by buying health items from a shop. 20 health costs 80 gold. Sure, you can buy an item that restores 40 health for 160 gold, or 120 health for 480 gold, but there is no discount as you go up. No incentive to buy better healing items. No reason to increase your max health until enemies literally one shot you.Moreover, the amount of damage the enemies do doesn't seem fair. They either do virtually no damage, or they do a TON of damage, but not much in between. So you are either just flying through an area virturally ignoring all the enemies, or you are using up all your health items in a five minute period.The voice acting isn't of the best quality either, which the exception of the main characters. When I talk to someone, I don't hear the character's voice. I hear a person trying to do a silly voice. As I talk to more characters, I can hear what is clearly just a small handfull of voice actors trying to do a bunch of different silly voices.Because of flaws like these and more, I wouldn't give the game a perfect score. But there is enough about it that IS done well that I will give it a positive score.

Posted: October 23, 2013
												Dust is a side scrolling RPG action platformer with surprisingly good aspects for an indie game. You play as Dust, a character weilding an ancient blade while suffering from memory loss. Although the idea has been used many times before, it carries out well for the story. The story itself is unique and I myself enjoyed wondering what could possibly occer next. The envierments range from forests to graveyards, snowy peaks to volcanic regions, all of which vividly colored and highly detailed. The animations for each character are smooth and the character models are great. Each NPC has an interesting personallity that defines them and I must applaud the voice acters for such a wonderful job. The humor is good enough to make me laugh a little, which gives a few lighthearted spots in the middle of all this seriousness. At times, the game will even break the forth wall, such as pointing out how you can pick up a sheep and store it in your inventory. The ending doesn't disappoint and personally left me a bit shaky. The downside of this game is, it's short. I clocked in at 12.2 hours after beating the game and that's doing the main quest, plus some side quests, plus screwing around. However, it's well worth the experiance of playing such an original game.My final rating: 8/10It's a fantasticly done game with little to no glitches and great storyline, however it is short.
