Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game has a terrible story, is full of used tropes, has a very basic combat system and no meaningful progression system - besides a Metroidvania set of abilities which allow you to progress, but barely alter gameplay.Yet it is absolutely amazing.The story doesn't matter, because what matters is the moment, what matters is the colourful characters and their compelling dialogues and unusual, yet on-point delivery. Yes when you look back on it, that story was bad - but did you reall care while playing?The tropes don't matter, because they are used well. I'll indulge myself in a stupid fetch quest for an ungrateful character if it allows me to screw him over.The basic combat system doesn't matter, because the floatiness of it all is exploited and becomes a game mechanics. I'd bet you were not supposed to do half the moves you can accomplish in this game. But they are incredibly satisfying to pull off regardless.The absence of progression system does not matter, because you will learn by playing that the tools at your disposal from the start can actually accomplish much more than you first thought. You learn by playing, in the moment.There are a LOT of things in this game that when considered on their own are completely unimpressive. But Dust:An Elysian Tale is the epitome of "greater than the sum of its parts". Everything just fits and works together. I never once looked back and say "uh that wasn't actually that great now that I think about" because I didn't need to. I was too busy enjoying fast-paced combos over a brilliant soundtrack, in a vivid magical world populated by weird species.If only the final chapter didn't completely crumble, this would have possibly been the absolute best experience I ever had. But as it stands now, it was just amazing.

Posted: October 5, 2016
												This is the first time I've written a review but this game has given me a reason to finally write one. Dust: An Elysian Tail is by far one of the best indie games I've ever played, if not one of the best games I've ever played in general. The combat is very responsive and fluid. The story is very engaging and manages to keep you interested from start to finish. The animations are very good and manage to look flashy while not being over the top. The story and writing is very well put together and it feels very natural. The voice acting is also really good.The only "cons" that I can think of, which are more just nitpicks than actual problems, are that the game in total is around 15 hours long but for an indie game that's pretty standard and you never feel bored the entire time you're playing. Another con is that the mouse and keyboard controls aren't the best. I'm not saying they're bad, it is possible to play this game soley with mouse and keyboard but I found that the game felt better when using a controller.There aren't any real problems with the game. The game runs smoothly at all times, it never crashes or anything like that and there aren't any game breaking bugs that I could find. You will encounter the occasional item getting stuck in a wall but it's nothing to be worried about.I highly recommend this game and give it a 10/10.

Posted: July 5, 2013
												A bit Castlevania, a bit Devil May Cry, a bit Secret of Mana. This game takes cues from good games old and new and combines them with modern sensibilities and original design to create something great. Beautiful visuals and memorable characters punctuate a touching story of a character with a conflicted origin, crossing both tragedy and epic heroism as the protagonist of the story, Dust, crafts his true destiny. Dust starts with little more than a vague recollection of times long past and quickly finds himself in a position to help those in need, and through his travels learns of dark deeds that have sunk the land into an oppressive sorrow, as well as his role in this situation, both past and present. Many would turn a blind eye or side with those who hold power, but there's something different about this one...It's well worth the paltry price being asked, if you enjoy broad gamplay and exploration. A combo system that allows you to juggle entire spawns of enemies and fly around like a madman, as well as tag team attacks allowing you to amp up your signature attack and become a human lightning rod, are combined with an action RPG leveling system and metroidvania exploration. Beatiful hand painted levels beg you to explore them and find every little hidden secret, with a surprising level of detail hidden around every corner.

Posted: July 31, 2016
												Alright-y. I have just finished the game with roughly 14 hours worth of playtime, and oh boy what a game. I loved it. The world was deep and rich with lore, all the characters were well rounded with ample story to give them plenty of life. The main character is well thought out in terms of his purpose and what makes him special. The game can be rather changing and isn't afraid to bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥♥if you aren't ready for it. And the in game secret challenges were well thought out and hard. For a long time I struggled with healing items making it a real challenge fighting all the enemies (specially the bigger ones).  Sometimes I struggled with the direction I had to go and I think that might just be because I was thick. The backdrops and scenery are GORGEOUS they are made so well and there is one in particular that was very eye catching (Giant♥♥♥♥♥statues).The bosses were amazing, and really challenging, especially the last boss he was a real challenge and I found it very fun to verse him even though I had to burn through all my healing items (even on normal holy♥♥♥♥♥♥. However it would have been nice if as I was fighting him the health bar didn't completely refill after every little story moment, it would have been far better to make one health bar and have it drain far slower then in the X number of times you have to fight him after a story moment (I wont tell you how many), both was though do tell you roughly how long the fight is going to go, my way leaves it less a mystery however. I thoroughly enjoyed the music and ambient noises (save for the mansions after you had to do a little running) and the voice acting was top quality though 2 or 3 voices had gotten a little grating at times.Overall it is a great game and I highly recommend it if you love side scrolling fighting games. The mechanics are just right for the game and the way it introduces it to you is just right, just watch out all that clicking may warrant a new mouse (Or J, K and L Keys). The music is perfect and the lore is able to pull you in and keep you interested in the world you are fighting for.9.6/10P.S. I have more hours then this. I just don't have a constant internet connection.

Posted: June 19, 2013
												It always makes me wonder why a game like this gets almost totally ignored by most mainstream players. Why? Is it because of the art style? Or the fact that it doesn't cost $120?Its a fairly smooth and enjoyable beat-em up with some platforming, RPG and questing elements which all mix in very well with one another. You typically won't get bored with the opponents and encounters due to their diversity and the art style is really well done - I'd love it if a certain universe of mine had even half the graphical quality this game has.It is a bit short, clocking in at around 7 to 8 hours but it really depends on the difficulty. If you play this, play on normal or higher - normal itself could be considered "easy" where easy could be considered "toddler" difficulty.It really doesn't have any flaws, it even controls well with the mouse and keyboard - argurably one of the smoothest controls I've ever used in a game like this. And, you will like the writing for the game, whoever wrote for Fidget needs to write for more games.9\10. No Multiplayer and lack of replay appeal if you beat the game on the hardest difficulty, and if you know me, I don't give high scores lightly - especially on these sorts of games.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												A short, but likeable game, Dust provides enough story to keep you interested, and gameplay fast and responsive enough to keep you engaged. At times the writing can get a bit threadbare, but there are some refreshing points, particularly the main antagonist. The voice acting is very good, and while the idea of a tiny comedic sidekick can be a cliché, Dust's answer is well rendered, actually useful, entertaining, and, perhaps most importantly, avoids being annoying.Yes, the writing could have gone leagues deeper, and I hate to say it, but I was less than thrilled with the ending. Still, I don't regret playing Dust, and if there's more to come someday, well, this setting definitely has life left in it.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												A game with a beautiful soundtrack, a lovely art-style, captivating characters, a unique story, ridiculously fun gameplay, deep character progression, great mechanics, and genious level design. Dust will please the completionists who want to spend hours getting all the little secrets and extras that modern games tend to leave out. I'm the kind of person who likes to seek out everything that is wrong with a game and then complain about it, because I believe it helps improve the specific game, as well as the industry in general, however, there are so very few things wrong with Dust that I shouldn't even mention them, really. Especially since they are things that I didn't like, but other people may enjoy quite profoundly. If you're thinking about buying Dust because you might like it, buy it, it's definitely my goty for 2013. Thanks for reading :)

Posted: February 15, 2014
												with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..the combat.ohhhh the combat.MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.IT IS PERFECT.there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												This game is amazing. Visually stunning once you realize ONE MAN did all the art, but prior to that is very pleasant if a bit "childish". However, don't let the appearance fool you. This art style might make you think of movies like An Americal Tail(note the name similarity?) or All Dogs Go to Heaven, but the game is not a kiddy game.For a metroidvania style game, something I don't usually care for, I have a great deal of fun playing it. Posted: December 7, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a truly special game.Done in the style of hand-drawn animation, while playing it I couldn't help feeling like I was back in my living room watching the Saturday morning caroons of my youth.  I did experience some display issues (flickering on the screen) but if you're like me, a child of the 80's,  and you experience it, I recommend pretending that you're just watching a well-worn VHS tape.  For me, that just added to the experience and even made it all the more endearing.The story is compelling and you'll likely get sucked in and want to play this exclusively until you get through it.  There are some fun Easter Eggs that you can unlock as you go along as well.  Additionally, the progression is nicely paced between leveling up and the gear that becomes available throughout - I never felt like Neo until the very end despite rarely feeling like I was in danger of dying.I chose not to 100% this game becuase I wanted to save myself some aggravation.  The collectables can be quite challenging to get (or even to find) but there is a wealth of information out there online should you choose to go that route.Between the nostalgic feel and comfortable gameplay, I would recommend this game to anyone.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a beautiful example of how to make a game when you don't have a Bethesda-class budget to play with.  The devs didn't try to go head-to-head with the latest hyper-realistic FPS or amazingly vast open world.  Instead, they took a very old, tried-and-true genre (the Metroidvania action platformer) and did it really well.The animation is smooth, and the sound is pleasant.  The storytelling allows itself some indulgent moments with overdramatic tropes, but then lightens up again with fourth-wall breaking, winking references to other games, and comedically petty sidequests for NPCs, rather than continually wallowing in melodrama.The style of gameplay is dated, and Dust can't compete on technical merits with big-studio offerings, but what makes this a pleasant experience is the degree of polish. Posted: December 5, 2014
												This game shows how you can still do some impressive stuff in two dimensions. The animations are wonderful, and there's so much fun to be had while slashing down enemies and finding loot around. The story itself is well developed and has several sidequests which make sense, and while there aren't dozens of them, they provide several hours of gameplay along with the main storyline. Graphic (and sound/music) wise this game is really well done, mostly in a way that makes it fun to watch and play through rather than for sheer beauty, but overall all of the characters and the places are well designed and stand out perfectly. If anything, sometimes the gameplay is repetitive, but that has mostly to do with the platform design rather than with the plot or the level design (imho), as the 2D nature of the game has some limits, but in the end the game makes really a lot to overcome each of its dimensional limits. For that matter, the amount and quality of both combos and movements of Dust make it fun to even just watch the character jumping in the air!In fact, while fighting you can also count on Fidget abilities, and some rings/pendants/etc greatly improve Fidget's combat skills, up to a point that lets you draw the fight style that suits you the most. RPG wise, this game allows you to craft several items but most of the crafting makes use of loot you can only find while killing enemies. That in turn makes for a solid system (as much as some backtracking) as it pushes you to play each area throughout, instead of buying most of what you need from a merchant.Overall, a really good game and especially a really good 2D platformer (with rpg elements), a good plot and a fighting system that makes for a lot of fun.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Dust provides a gameplay experience much like any other in its genre.  The control feel (I used gamepad) is fluid and easy to pick up.  The brawling mechanism is redundant at times, particularly when you are grinding to push yourself one more level on the tougher difficulties.  Animation in this game is truly something that kept me in it for the long haul.  The soundtrack is good enough that you don't really give it a second thought while playing, however its not the best by any means.  Characters in this game are likable (even more so if you are a fan of furries) however the story felt lacking in my opinion.  Slight changes here and there could have made this an extraordinarily memorable experience however without them I am left after two full playthroughs (120% completion) simply satisfied.  Great game if you can get it on sale or in a bundle.  There are some fairly interesting side plots to occupy time and for the purpose of extending game run time and this game has a tendency to give major throwbacks to old school gaming that always put a smile on my face.  I definitely recommend playing it through at least once to anyone who is in to this sort of metroid-esque game.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Moderately fun side scrolling hack and slash plat forming RPG game. Played on the second hardest difficulty with a usb playstation controller and it took about 10 hours to beat it just doing the main quest line. About 2 hours of that was just grinding because I didn’t bother with the crafting system so my gear wasn’t that good. The enemies are not that difficult until you get to the last area. The greatest challenge came from the platforming as jumps were often very difficult to make. Your regular jump often does not reach high enough so you have to attack in mid air to get that extra height boost, but this makes sticking your landing in the right spot more difficult. You also often just randomly fall through platforms when you land on them which can be frustrating. I also had to restart the game on several occasions because I would just randomly fall through and get stuck inside of walls. The good thing is there are a lot of save points so even if you get stuck you don't have to restart that far back. The story line/dialog is kind of cringey, but I just skipped most of it. The environment looks pretty nice, but sometimes it is hard to tell what you can jump on or what hurts you as the background and foreground kind of blend in with the main area at times. I wouldn’t recommend buying this game at full price, but since it was included in the humble bundle 11 you can probably get it for cheap.

Posted: May 28, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action side-scrolling platformer game with a very fluid combo system and well animated attacks, giving the player a sense of simply being awesome in combat. I've played a lot of games, but nothing is quite as unique as Dust. The game gives the player the ability to move freely throughout the world, going to whichever areas they so desire to rack-up XP, explore or find hidden secrets in past levels. The story in Dust is one surrounded by mystery, the protagonist, Dust, starts off with amnesia and cannot recollect a damn thing about his past, which I know is very cliche but it suits Dust's story just fine. The protagonist is alway accompanied by a cat-ferret-bat creature by the name of Fidget (who is also the cutest damn thing I've seen since Tali in Mass Effect), who offers humorous dialogue and grants the player a ranged attack. To clarify: I f*cking love Fidget.Dust's combat system flows beautifully, utilizing a mere three buttons for attacks, the combat is simple but at the same time awe inspiring, easy to pick up on and very well made, when the player whipes out his/her first batch of enemies you immediately feel like an incredible badass and leaves you itching for more. As the game proceeds you acquire new abilities that complement your already formidible attack options and keep the game from getting stale, all the while maintaining a steady difficulty curve alongside an easy to understand XP and level-up system.Graphics-wise: It's an indy game, you don't come into it expecting mind-blowing graphics. Dust uses a simple but lovable anthropomorphic cartoon art-style that is both charming and outright adorable, but also dark and serious when it needs to be. All perfected with an amazing musical score and top quality voice acting. As well, Dust makes numerous quips at the expense of the fourth wall and makes references to other games, like Resident Evil 4 and Castlevania. The one flaw I've seen thus far is a somewhat finicky platform system. Sometimes if you don't land on a platform at exactly the right angle you're going through, which in a platformer game is a real kick to the groin.In conclusion: Dust: An Elysian Tail is fun, fluid, and highly addictive. I definitely recommend anyone reading this to pick it up immediately.

Posted: July 5, 2013
												A bit Castlevania, a bit Devil May Cry, a bit Secret of Mana. This game takes cues from good games old and new and combines them with modern sensibilities and original design to create something great. Beautiful visuals and memorable characters punctuate a touching story of a character with a conflicted origin, crossing both tragedy and epic heroism as the protagonist of the story, Dust, crafts his true destiny. Dust starts with little more than a vague recollection of times long past and quickly finds himself in a position to help those in need, and through his travels learns of dark deeds that have sunk the land into an oppressive sorrow, as well as his role in this situation, both past and present. Many would turn a blind eye or side with those who hold power, but there's something different about this one...It's well worth the paltry price being asked, if you enjoy broad gamplay and exploration. A combo system that allows you to juggle entire spawns of enemies and fly around like a madman, as well as tag team attacks allowing you to amp up your signature attack and become a human lightning rod, are combined with an action RPG leveling system and metroidvania exploration. Beatiful hand painted levels beg you to explore them and find every little hidden secret, with a surprising level of detail hidden around every corner.

Posted: May 21, 2015
												This game encompasses everything I love about video games. The graphics are beautiful, the story is engaging, and the music draws you right in. This is, however, an action RPG/Metroidvania, so none of that would matter if the gameplay and level design wasn't up to snuff. Luckily, that's not the case. The controls are tight and snappy. Dust does exactly what you want him to do, when you want him to do it. Although more simplistic, I almost felt a Devil May Cry influence in the combat. It's action packed and relentless. The level design is varied and entertaining. I eagerly looked forward to what I was going to find on the next screen. The enemy designs were also quite good. The headless zombie things in the third section made me smile every time I saw them. The one complaint I have with this game is the same one everyone else has. The boss fights. While not bad, they just don't measure up to the rest of the game and they're definitely a bit on the easy side. But you should absolutely not let that one small thing stop you from experiencing this game.Dust: An Elysian Tail is just plain fun, no matter how you look at it. I can't wait to play it again on a harder difficulty once I get through some of my backlog and I'll eagerly await a sequel.9.5/10

Posted: June 27, 2013
												You will often find, among gamers and critics alike, diverse opinions that state the positives and negatives of various games, with things such as "the game is good" or "the game was too short" or "the controls suck."This is not the case with Dust: An Elysian Tail.  I have been a gamer my entire life, ostracized as a child in school by the very people now addicted to Call of Duties and Madden NFLs.  I have watched the evolution of gaming from the 8-and-16-bit era of Mario and Sonic, the evolution of PC gaming from text based RPGs to DragonAge and Skyrim.Of all the games I have played, from casual Runescape to the intensely cerebral Europa Universalis, from the flashy twitch gaming of Smash Brothers to the thought-out fights of Guild Wars.  "Dust: An Elysian Tail" is by far one of the most defining creations in the Gaming Industry.  What makes it more spectacular and amazing is the story of a single man hand-drawing and developing the game from scratch over years, of an indie developer given a chance on Xbox Arcade.Dead Dodrill has brought to us a game that, in collaboration with secondary writer Alex Kain, and composers Alexander Brandon and HypderDuck Soundworks, defines everything we love about gaming.  He brings us back to the core elements of a video game.I can say, without a doubt in my mind, that Dust: An Elysian Tail is, by far, the greatest representation of Video Games as an Artform.  If there ever any confusion or concern if games could be consider Art, Dead Dodrill has proved us otherwise.No amount of praise I could give would satisfy my love for this game.  For 17 years, Blizzard Entertainment's Starcraft franchise has held a special place in my heart as my favorite game of all time.  Upon completion of this artistic masterwork, I can say that this has changed.Dean Dodrill, Alexander Brandon, and everyone else that not only made this game possible, but brought it to the attention of the general public.  I thank you, and I heartily reccommend this game for anyone.

												I'm a bit late to discovering this game. However, Dust is probably one of the greatest 2D games I've played, and I personally had a lot of fun with the time I've spent on it. The fact that one guy did both of the programming and artwork by himself for this wonderful game is astounding and praisworthy. The list below shows more specific pieces of my opinion:Pros:- Great artwork, the style is quite colorful and lively.- Fairly large world with a variety of settings.- Combat system is fun to play around with, high combos feel rewarding.- Music is superb, fits the world perfectly and sets the tone just right.- Story is paced well.- Secrets in the levels are fun to discover and even feel rewarding later on in the game.- Good length and packed with content for the pricetag.Cons:- Combat can feel a bit restricted after playing for a bit.- Way too easy; the difficulty suddenly goes from super simple to sorta easy near the end. 												I want to start off by saying that this is an amazing Indie game. The gameplay is smooth and fast paced - which hardly ever leaves you in distaste. The graphics are well drawn and keeps a consistent style across the entire game. Sound and music is well crafted also. Equipment system could see more improvements in customisation apart from purely modifying stats (e.g. affecting movement speed, giving your blade an elemental animation). The combat could see more variants in attacks and longer chain combos, including more types of projectiles to be shot. Story is captivating and the dialogue is humourous and enjoyable. This game can be finished in less than 10 hours if you blitz through the storyline, but unlocking everything will take a bit longer. Overall an enjoyable game - would recommend it to any platformer fan!

Posted: September 2, 2014
												Phew... It's everything but easy to write a review to this game.To be honest, if this game had been published from a major company, I might have been disappointed. But it is an Indie-Game (and the first one Noogy ever made), so naturally one cannot compare it to a major release.All in all it is a really great game, hands down. ;)Now enough talk, let's get to the likes and dislikes.Likes:absolutely gorgeous artwork and animationsan overwhelming soundtracksmooth and action oriented gameplaygreat voice actingan absolutely cute and funny sidekickfunny innoendos about video game oddities (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)unintrusive and funny 4th wall breaksnice refferences to other games  (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)perhaps not innovative but nevertheless interesting aproach on crafting and trading (increasing the trader's assortment by selling new items to them)the Mysterious Wall Chicken!Dislikes:level grinding and item/gold farming is way too easyFidget becomes way too overpowered (I stopped using her powers at the meadows to keep the game halfway challenging, although I cranked up the difficulty before)speaking of challenge: the first and the last boss fights were the only ones which were challenging to me, the latter perhaps only because I didn't use fidgetevery health item stronger than the Mysterious Wall Chicken! is a bad bargain to buy (using 2 chickens heals 160 hp for 600 coins, the hot cocoa heals 160 hp for 640 coins, the birthday cake has an even worse cost-benefit ratio, so you end up swallowing countless chickens because it is the cheapest way to heal - but Mysterious Wall Chicken FTW!, so why should I care? :D )About the story... well, I'm actually a bit torn appart about it.Yes, it follows quite common tropes and is per se not that innovative, but it IS a good story and keeps you interested, if you alow yourself to delve into it.But there are two major drawbacks about the story. The first and the most disappointing is that major plot elements are revealed waaaaaayyyy too early. In Aurora Ginger tells you that you're dressed like a royal assassin - first half of the plot revealed, and shortly after someone tells you about a "twin soul" - not sure if Fuse allready talks about it, but Lady Tethys most certainly does and thus revealing the other half of the plot.So roughly after the first third of the game you can allready figure out what is going on, only the "when, where and why" is kept a secret until the near end.The second drawback about the Story is that "it seems to be a bit shallow". That's one thing often critizised at negative reviews about Dust. Well, i dare to disagree, hence the quotation marks.I think the story itself is not that shallow (at least not more shallow than the Halo-Storyline *duck and cover*), but it is told in a shallow fashion. The arcs of suspense are boiled down to short cutscenes with only a few lines of dialouge and major plot twists are given away early and in a way as if they were only a negligibility.So I say the Story would gain more positive reviews if it was told in a different way and revealed in a "different order".Well, yes, this was quite a bit of a breakdown, pointing out more negative features than positive ones.But: Every positive feature mentioned outweights the negative ones by far.It is an absolutely great game and mindblowingly detailed - especially if you take into consideration that this is the first game ever released by Noogy. Thats why I give this Game a thumbs up - I absolutely love it!Oh and in case you haven't noticed yet: I friggin' LOVE the mysterious wall chicken !!! :D

Posted: March 8, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is visually stunning, the writing is excellent, and the control system's responsive. The world and the characters in it are unique and interesting. Voice acting's versatile and brilliant. Gameplay wise, the difficulty is perfect. The enemies are not invincible, but are by no means are cakewalk either. As in any good combat-heavy game, the combat system is simple, but flexible. I've heard many people say that the bosses in this game are too easy, but I still find them challenging enough. I don't think Dust: An Elysian Tail intended that the bosses be particularly difficult; I think they intended for bosses to be links in the story and chances to show off their brilliant game - and level design. For those who find bosses too easy, or just want a more intense expirience, you can always up the difficulty level. Magic spam is a viable strategy in this game, but in order to pull it off you need to focus 100% of the time. Personally, I don't think it's a problem, nothing in this game is broken or unbeatable. All in all, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a diamond, and a valuable diamond to be precise. This game is in my list of top 10 games ever made, and I would recommend it to anyone who is even somewhat interested in getting it.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a side scrolling beat em' up with beautiful 'hand painted' backgrounds, and an exciting story about an amnesia-stricken warrior fighting his way through many unique environments to try and remember who he is.Though the game starts off with a Shadow the Hedgehog vibe, and the dialogue can be sorta cheesy (At least Fidget's, who fits in as the over-excited side kick who doesn't stop talking), it branches away from the "edgy furry confused with the world" as the prologue progresses, and Fidget sorta grows on me.Update:After finishing the game, I can safely say that it was amazing. I didn't finish all the sidequests/get all the treasure yet, but I have about 14 hours on the game. Pretty good amount of gameplay for the money I spent on it. (On sale for $3), but even if I bought it at normal price, it would be worth every penny. The combat in the game is pressing either the right and left mouse buttons, or J and K. All of your attacks will be done with these keys, and you can with dodge/dash forward with Q and E. I've seen people complain how the combat gets stale, but that's not true. Each enemy is designed to be fought a certain way, and you're forced to think strategically when fighting many of them at once. One enemy can be killed with simple melee attacks while the another enemy will parry all of your attacks, and you must strike him right as he's about to attack in order to land a blow on him. This can prove difficult in the later rounds, but it also keeps the game interesting.My only real complaint about the game is the boss difficulty. In Normal Mode, the bosses are not that hard. The first boss is one of the easiest intimidating bosses I've ever fought, so I was a bit disappointed, especially because he's a key part of the story. You'd think he'd prove more difficult to fight. Each boss, obviously gets harder to fight, and the final boss fight is very satisfying in terms of difficulty. But the difficulty in general seemed too easy, but perhaps I'll just need to replay the game on Hard mode.To conclude;The story is great, the designs are great, and while many people will ignore the game solely because of the animal characters, I'm glad I gave this game a shot. The combat is exciting, the enemies are unique, the environments are beautiful and the story is compelling. While some bosses are too easy ( or I'm too good :^) ), the Final Boss stands as quite a challenge, and defeating him rewards you with an ending that truly settles the dust.I'd give it a 9/10, I highly reccomend it.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Holy wow. Look at this artwork. I originally bought the game just because it was so amazingly pretty, and started playing it with the thought that the story would be terrible and the voice acting mediocre. Boy, was I wrong. The story is so compelling that it drew me in, even when I wasn't even planning to let myself be drawn in by it. And for indie voice actors/actresses, these people have done a stellar job. As far as combat is concerned, this combat is amazingly satisfying. I'm not terribly into hack-and-slashes, but this one does a stellar job of making you feel like a powerful warrior by giving you lots of intuitive combos and such. And if you're like me and you just want to mash one or two buttons, there's a lot of different combos with just the left and right mouse buttons, which really makes you want to stop mashing buttons and think about what you're doing instead. It works beautifully.It's hard to believe that this is a console port, but it is, and the port was done so amazingly well that it's far better than most native PC games I've played.Of course, the question of furries always comes up with anthropomorphic animals (Like those that appear in this game). From what little I've seen, furry art tends to be... well, furry. The characters here are clean-cut and undersexualized in comparison, and really look more like Looney Tunes than anything else. I'll be honest; I'm not into anthro stuff at all, but these characters are drawn well enough that I don't mind. And what 90's kid grew up without Looney Tunes? Well, a few, obviously, but the rest of us didn't care at the time about anthro-looking characters, so why care now?Anyway, overall this game is stellar, and I'm mighty impressed with the cool stuff this guy did with a seemingly simple engine. Did I mention this game was made by one guy? This game was made by one guy. And you can feel the love he poured into every pore. And hey, if nothing else, go into this game to wander around and admire the scenery. It's beautiful.

												I played and won this game on the Xbox, so when it went on sale on Steam, it was an easy buy. - Fantastic graphics- Great story, almost brings tears at times- Good range of difficulty levels- Many fun side quests to either complete along the way or to come back to later- Combat structure makes you feel like a boss- Runs smoothly on even low performance computers- It takes about 5-10 hours to win the game, not necissarily doing all the quests and getting all the chests, but it's certainly worth playing more than once

Posted: July 9, 2014
												A 2D brawler with RGG elements of character progession, loot and quests Dust: An Elysian Tail has no right to be nearly as good as it actually is. It is an excellent metroidvania style game.The graphics are slick and colourful and the animation is smooth, fast and very energetic. The only times the quality wanes in in some of the few animated cut scenes which look on par with an average flash animationGameplay wise the titular character feels very responsive, I've never felt screwed by the game, only myself. the sides quests are nothing much more than kill or fetch quests but the loot system feels effective without being useless or completely overpowered. There is also basic crafting to create your items of power from the 30 or so crafting materials that can drop from varied monsters spread out over several zones. To do everything in the game is roughly 20 hours gameplay which is not only good value for money but like portal it means the game progress at a rate that feels like your moving forward rather than killing time and you end up finishing the game long before it outstays it's welcome. The characters and style have been crafted in the same mold as the animated movie 'An American Tail' albeit with an anime twist. An odd yet comfortable creation. Unfortuantely you never get much time with many of the side characters so they can appear very 1 dimensional. the story likewise is fairly simplistic but with some nice twists in the tale to keep things fresh. What really helps though is the excellent voice acting, nothing on par with something like Bioshock or Mass Effect but more like an excellent dub of an anime, which considering the art style works very, very well. You do have a typical anime style sidekick though and it is entirely possible you could hate them, that is up to you to decide.Speaking of the sound the music track is probably the only part of the game not composed by the creator of the game, Thankfully it is likewise excellent, providing all the right moods at the right time from energetic, daramatic compositions to some tracks providing a sense of unease in a haunted house.Being a port of an Xbox Live game you will be suprised to know the port is one of the best ever. In anything. Large publishers have been royally put to shame with the amount of options a PC user can change in the settings from basic visuals and FX settings to physically putting the HUD anywhere you like on the screen. Anywhere. As an addition the animations themselves are either the best upscale from 720p I have ever seen or they went back to the original art and took higher resolution images to be used in the PC port.All in all Dust: An Elysian Tail is one mans labour of love and it really shows. As long as you don't mind the obligatory talking found in RPG's, don't hate anime, and are a fan or even curious about metroidvania games this needs to be in your collection. Don't even bother with a thumbs up or down on this review, just buy the game.

												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a beautifull game with great controlls amazing art, music the voice acting feels very natural for most if not all of the character's and it's a game with a great story, the combat seems rather simplistic at first but it is fun and did not feel boring to me at all with the addition of combos that you can pull off and moves that you can do and for a 2D platformer/Beat-em up/RPG type deal it does alot of things very well and it makes me overjoyed that we can get games like this. There are so many good things about this game and it is a must play for just about everyone.

Posted: October 2, 2014
												For a game made by a one man dev team, Dust plays beautifully. Combos are exciting and the support character Fidget tosses in variety to combat. It just feels so smooth. Add this to the dynamic art, and it's superb.*On the subject of art, don't avoid this game just because of the furry people. You would truly miss out. Luckily, the tight game mechanics and great art and music save the game from its poor story and dialogue. It is as predictable as its characters. On one hand, the voice acting is good; on the other, the dialogue is bland. General Gaius, the main villian, is the worst. His reasons for genocide include... it's his world? His character is baseless. For literally the entire game, I was waiting for Gaius's character to be explored in some way. It is confusing, because his lines give the impression that he believes that he is the good guy. Thus, I would have liked a backstory, or maybe some kind of reveal.I recommend this game, but don't look for a rewarding story.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												Okay, here's the short version of this review.This game is absolutely AMAZING!!!Now for the long version of this review.Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most well-crafted video games I have ever played, and it's easily in my top 5 favourite games of all time.  The gameplay is insanely satisfying; any fans of hack-and-slashes or Metroidvanias will most likely enjoy this game big-time.  The story is well-written and surprisingly dark for such a colourful world, and the game puts a lot of emphasis on pretty much every character in the game, even the minor characters!The visuals of this game, in my opinion, might be the best I've ever seen in any video game.  This game's visuals are absolutely BREATHTAKING, especially when the weather effects kick in.  You will not believe how many times I was at a loss of words for how beautiful the game looked at times (you should've seen me when I got to Blackmoor Mountain XD).  As for the soundtrack, it's straight-up majestic.  The OST is beautifully composed, and help capture the mood for pretty much every scene they're assigned.The only complaints that I really have with this game are that the boss fights are pretty meh (with the exception of the game's final boss), but even then, there's so few bosses in the game that it's not a major issue; plus, the characterization given to the bosses is actually really impressive.  The only other issue I have with the game is that Chapter 3 is pretty pointless and, admittedly, kinda boring, but the rest of the game makes up for it in spades.So, long story short, if you have the money for this game and you're just staring at the store page wondering if you should click on that Add to Cart button, I'd say that you should.  Chances are, you will not be disappointed by this game.  I sure wasn't.9.5/10

Posted: August 3, 2016
												When I first saw this game it caught me off guard with the whole side scrolling RPG adventure style, I bought it and played through it from start to finish on hardcore on my first playthrough, it was quite fun with the small flawless challenge. You could die just as easy to enemies as you could kill them, I had my fair share of deaths as well as victories. But I can't deny how beautiful this game is. The unique worlds and weathers that comes with it, biomes and new challenges all around the corner. Characters you can grow to love and hate. You feel feel emmersed in this game as you can't help but feel like Dust. You're thrown into this strange world with no memory or clue as to what's going on or what you're doing. And with a gentle little shove from Ahrah, you're well on your way into a journey around this glorious landcape. I love it's simple yet facinating design and exploration. You can explore places that has NOTHING to do with the main quest line, just to feed that inner adventurer in you or do a good deed. I'm honestly surprised by the amount of potentioal in this game despite being locked in a side scrolling dimension, it still manages to show off so much. It's incredible how well they combined all the genres into this one massive scape. Exploring this beautiful world that surrounds you, filled with details and epic particles. While fending off foes along your journey. You grow close to the characters in this world and really notice the unique traits and personalities. Which makes it so much more emotional for you as you continue onwards. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a challenge, adventure or simply just want to enjoy the beauty some things can offer. The experiences I had from this game will be some I will never forget, I will carry them with me til' the Life Thread calls. And I hope anyone else who sets out on this journey will come to love and hate it as much as I have! Farewell for now though, dust to dust, ashes to ashes.  I've become quite the fanboy, haven't I?

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Wow, what an amazing game. "Dust: An Elysian Tail" tell the story of Dust, a being who has no recollection of who he is but soon encounters a duo of companions ready to accompany him on his journey of discovery: a talking sword named Ahrah, one of the fabled Blades of Elysium, and its protector, a cute, little, nimbat by the name of Fidget. Together they will help Dust piece together his memories and defeat the evil General Gaius.This game plays pretty much like Castlevania and Dust incorporates new abilities as he progresses the story, abilities that are required to access areas previously unreachable so there is some backtracking. Dust levels up automatically so there's no manually assigning stats (this is only true for casual difficulty, in harder modes you can choose between manual and automatic stat assignment). The inventory lets you customize his armour, sword enhancement, rings, and pendant, plus there's a slot for food, which provides different types of healing, and another one for an odd assortment of items, from teleportation gems to treasure keys. Items can be bought at merchant posts or, alternatively, you'll find blueprints that'll allow you to craft your own, provided you have the necessary materials.Combat is very fluid and feels extremely powerful what can sometimes compensate for its repetitive nature. At some point, I decided to use the Dust Storm with Projectiles combo to settle conflicts quickly. Indeed, you can use it to defeat 90% of all enemies in the game without a hitch. So if you're looking for a game where you need to strategize combats, this isn't it.The dialogue and voice acting is surprisingly good and Fidget easily became my favourite. If this game has one glaring problem is that the instances where Dust gets to talk to Fidget or any other character in the game are separated by tons of combat and when they do appear they bombard you with lots of it. Personally, I would have preferred more, if shorter, dialogue events between fights to break up the monotony of combat.Needless to say, both the soundtrack and the art style are superb. The story has some twists and turns and, certainly, a few plot points are not explained as thoroughly as I would've liked (some not at all). I also think Dust reacted surprisingly well to the main twist, maybe even too much so. Some measure of outrage would not have been out of place I believe. However, none of this detracts from the fact that I connected with these characters to the point I shed a few tears at some heartwrenching moments despite having seen them coming from a mile away. It is that good."Dust: An Elysian Tail" puts many AAA titles to shame. It's a purchase well worth full price, clocking around 11 hours at around 85% completion, and an experience you won't forget anytime soon. I for one am looking forwards to playing more Elysian Tails...

Posted: June 27, 2016
												Ok, first review ever, so GO:First Impression:Nice graphics, witty dialogues, and perhaps a bit few combo possibilities.So, then into details:Graphics:They are not as breathtaking as maybe Ori, but they are nice enough that you still enjoy looking at them even after some hours of playing. The advantage of the more simple 2D-style: they don't need much resources. Gameplay:As mentioned at the beginning, you don't have that many different combos, that you can use. This seems like a something bad, but except for people looking for a real challange, they suffice, as the enemies are not the smartest, even on hard. This leads to the next point, the difficulty. If you complete most of the quests and keep track of the items and plans you collected, you can finish of most of the enemies with one or at most two combos, even on hard. This game is more suited for a bit of casual gaming, whenever you don't want to tax yourself too hard.Story:I completed a complete playthrough with all hidden objects and all the best upgrades for Dust within ~15 h. As I took my time, you could probably finish the main story with some side-quests on the way in 8 h. This should give a rough estimate of the amount of story you can expect. The story itself is told mostly in dialogues, except for some sequences at the very beginning and the very end, overall with pretty decent voice-acting. Arguably the best thing of the game: the funny dialogues, especially the banter between dust, the hero, and fidget, the flying companion, which is afraid of heights.... What I personally really liked were the many more or less hidden tributes to other games, in the dialogues or the within the world itself. Can you find them all?I won't write much about the content of the story, as I hate spoilers. Its not groundbreaking, but very solid. You may guess the twist, but nevertheless, you can sympathise well with the characters, and thats what matters to me.So overall a neat game, for some funny casual gaming to get down after a tough day, or a tough gaming session. ;)If you got this far, thanks for reading and cherio!Atlan

Posted: July 5, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tale is one of the best side scrolling action platformer out there! It features a great story, some rpg elements and some metroidvania style upgrades! You control Dust on his quest to find who he is and you are accompanied by 2 quite colorful characters, the blade of Ahrah, a sentient artifact sword that has a serious and mentor-like character and that you use for combat, and Fidget, the guardian of the sword and a comical character overall, she will make you giggle quite many times!Firsts things first! The visuals are marvelously pleasing, an eye candy of sorts! The animations for both Dust and the enemies feel fluid and clean making combat a good feature instead of a filler through the story parts. The sounds and music as well as voice acting are right on point making the game an even greater gaming experience. To add to that the story is really compelling as you will find yourself, quite many times, in a spot where you will want to play just a bit more to uncover the next part. To add to that it’s the type of the game where I didn’t want to finish, as the gameplay, along with the story left me with a void when I finished it.The main features of the game is its combat and exploration. The combat can be as easy or as demanding as you like, as the games difficulty affects this aspect only. Easy difficulty will result in enemies dying easily and doing less damage as well as you healing at check points, while higher difficulties can result in certain enemies being able to kill you if you don’t counter at the right time. Generally you have your base attacks and combos that you can do with Ahrah, and with Fidgets help you can unleash a powerful duststorm that will serve as your aoe attack. Small and normal sized enemies, besides bosses, do not require any special approach. However bigger enemies, like rock giants and trolls, can be a threat! Shield wielding enemies are immune to frontal attacks and since they will always face you, you need to counter their attack in order to stun them. While stunned all enemies take a lot more damage, so countering does feel rewarding no matter the enemy!  If you want that extra satisfaction from this game, I recommend higher difficulties for your first playthrough.As you progress the game you will earn experience and upgrades for your skills. Experience is gained from completing quests, main or side, talking to characters and by killing enemies. Additionally while you kill enemies you can chain hit them, resulting in a combo meter, after the combat ends you will get additional experience depending your combo meter! Each level up will give you a stat point that you can use to increase 1 out of 4 base stats. Attack, Defense, Health and Fidged (yes she is actually a stat too!). The first 3 are obvious to what they offer, Fidget on the other hand increases the potency of your aoe, the duststorm. Personally this was my favored stat as I used duststorm a lot and because you will find gear that sadly overshadows the increase one skill point adds to that stat.  Also as you venture the lands of Elysium you will encounter certain shrines that will either augment a skill or give you a new one, skills like sliding or climbing are in this category. Finally after each major boss you will get an upgrade for duststorm, giving Fidged a new element for it! The cool part of this system is that you get to visit older areas, that were previously had an exit out of reach, to find secrets or easter eggs and the challenges! The challenges are hidden rooms with speedrun courses. You do not have to ace them to get the reward but if you like the challenge you can try get those 4 stars! All these are marked to your map, so you can see each areas completion and where is something hidden, the twist is, that besides that info, you do not have detailed map of each area, so you need to explore it yourself!The controls are easy to grasp and fully customizable, keyboard or controller. Having tried both I did not find a more favorable, it depends on your playstyle!The only negative of the game is its crafting feature. Throughout the game you will find blueprints for gear that once you gather the materials required you cab craft. However quite many times the vendor offered the best version for a slot or even after making a good gear for a slot, inferior gear and blueprints dropped. Generally I did not get to use the crafting system that much since I rarely got an actual upgrade.Overall, Dust: An Elysian Tale is a great game, and a game that definitely is worthy of its price! I recommend it with my eyes closed!-------------------------------------------I reviewed this game for the steamified group.For similar reviews and great giveaways feel free to visit http://www.steamified.com

There is also basic crafting to create your items of power from the 30 or so crafting materials that can drop from varied monsters spread out over several zones. To do everything in the game is roughly 20 hours gameplay which is not only good value for money but like portal it means the game progress at a rate that feels like your moving forward rather than killing time and you end up finishing the game long before it outstays it's welcome. The characters and style have been crafted in the same mold as the animated movie 'An American Tail' albeit with an anime twist. An odd yet comfortable creation. Unfortuantely you never get much time with many of the side characters so they can appear very 1 dimensional. the story likewise is fairly simplistic but with some nice twists in the tale to keep things fresh. What really helps though is the excellent voice acting, nothing on par with something like Bioshock or Mass Effect but more like an excellent dub of an anime, which considering the art style works very, very well. You do have a typical anime style sidekick though and it is entirely possible you could hate them, that is up to you to decide.Speaking of the sound the music track is probably the only part of the game not composed by the creator of the game, Thankfully it is likewise excellent, providing all the right moods at the right time from energetic, daramatic compositions to some tracks providing a sense of unease in a haunted house.Being a port of an Xbox Live game you will be suprised to know the port is one of the best ever. In anything. Large publishers have been royally put to shame with the amount of options a PC user can change in the settings from basic visuals and FX settings to physically putting the HUD anywhere you like on the screen. Anywhere. As an addition the animations themselves are either the best upscale from 720p I have ever seen or they went back to the original art and took higher resolution images to be used in the PC port.All in all Dust: An Elysian Tail is one mans labour of love and it really shows. As long as you don't mind the obligatory talking found in RPG's, don't hate anime, and are a fan or even curious about metroidvania games this needs to be in your collection. Don't even bother with a thumbs up or down on this review, just buy the game.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Dust defines itself very well in action platformer genre with a mix of RPG element. It's battle mechanic let you freely perform a mix of ground combats, aerial combats, and magics to built up combo counter for better bonus exp and bonus item drops. Every level up grants you a point to increase one of the four stat category (HP, Attack, Defend, and Magic). This game also offer you sidequests to explore in each regions for hidden items, bonus, blueprint (to crafting accessory), and lot of references from other games. Most regions on the world map in this game are big and has a lot of room to explore.Personally, I am really enjoy Dust as for it's RPG element and lot of contents to explor in each regions in the game. All hidden chests in this game are not really well hidden though, the game rather focus to challenge your skill of a platformer than a puzzle skill; making this game quite enjoyable and enthertain to most audiences. Also, most hidden chests contain several kinds of materials and blueprints, a solid rewards of exploration in this game is to finding these blueprints which most likely to grant you access to a better gear quickly.There are two big flaws in this game, one fall in a repeatitive battle mechanics and one fall in a flat story. Player will get access to several new items and new magic while advancing the main quest, however, none of them significantly affect the play style. You will fall back to performing a usaul mix of ground, aerial, and magic all the entire game. Enemies in this game may receives a uniques identity in each regions (each chapters) but all of them mostly fall to the same three major types consist of Normal size, Big size, and Flying type; the strategy to fight off these three types throughout the game are the same, offer not much of a challenge to the player when accessing to a new area (except for higher HP and higher damage). I also found another disappointment in it's story. If you only focus on the movement of main story and main protagonist then you may find an enjoyment to some extent, but it is very sad that other major characters received no solid background and being rendered as pure good and pure evil with no clear reason; making the story simply not very interesting, at least to me. Also, at first the game seem like to grant player a freedom to make his own decision that could affect other characters (this option even significantly apply to one of the sidequests) but that's that. This freedom simply disappear in the later of the game.The final word is I really love this game. A metroidvania gamer like myself may find the most comfort in this game from exploration, it is simply fun to explore chests, get blueprints, and farming for materials. The amount of sidequests throughout the game are not much but, at least, acceptable. Even though the combat mechanic is quit repeatitive, it is still fun to roaming around the field with what the game has to offers. Also, Dust was actually released in 2012 so it is assumable for the game to receives a huge discount at this time. I recommend this is a good Action/platformer game you should at least try with no worry about it's prices when compare to all contents you will find in the game.

Posted: September 27, 2015
												One word to describe it? Mindblown.The moment I saw the screenshots and trailer for this game, I knew this game could be something special and I was ABSOLUTELY RIGHT! To put it simply:1. Story? Great story that both young and old audiences can enjoy.2. Characters? Very lovable characters (expect for the obvious "bad" guys lol) and I really like that most of them had "side quests" when talking to them and not just have them standing there, talking to you once and never hear from them again. I found myself revisiting a lot of them frequently, solving their issues as well as being rewarded for completing those side quests. Definitely love this approach!3. Graphics? Simply BEAUTIFUL/GORGIOUS WORLD with stunning views in almost all areas. While admittedly it took me some time to adapt to it (especially while running and fighting enemies), I got adapted to it rather quickly and have thoroughly enjoyed every level I played not just for the story/fights but also for observing the surrounding beautiful landscapes as well.4. Music? Absolutely brilliant! The music was calming at times, intense at other times, but it was always fitting to the scene and really helped get me totally "immersed" in the atmosphere of this great game!5. Fighting? Very fluid and you get more abilities (as well as power-ups for your companion "Fidget") as you progress so that you can revisit old areas and unlock hidden chests in areas that you weren't able to reach previously. Though, my ONLY "criticism" of this entire game is that, while you get new abilities/power-ups, you do NOT get any "new combos" as you progress, meaning you are stuck doing the SAME combos over and over again from start to the end of this game. So as a note to developers, for future similar games, please add more new combos to decrease the "repetitiveness" of killing the enemies with the same old combos over and over again.Nonetheless, the one criticism above does NOT have any major impact on my enjoyment of this game. Definitely a "must-buy" for those who enjoy stories that are told in an old style "cartoony" fashion with FULL VOICE ACTING for all dialogues as well as those who just enjoy side-scrolling fighting games in general.Final Rating: 10/10. (And hoping for a FUTURE SEQUEL to this game as well! :D)

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Now before i begin my review, i have to say something first:If it weren't for an animated SFM video about Fidget, and my curiosity about why Fidget is so adorable, i never would've discovered this game. I'm so glad i did, though.Now the actual review:This game is what first looks like a MetroidVania, beat-em up, adventure game. But it's way more than that. The entire game is pure epic. The gameplay is intense and fun, the story is eventful and heart-pounding, the cast of characters are ALL lovable (I <3 Fidget), and the music is outstanding!The biggest thing i love about this game though, is especially the story and the characters. All of the characters have unique personality (Dust is cool, Fidget is childishly cute, Ahrah is the serious one of the main trio, and even the each NPCs have unique personalities) The dialogues in the game are hilarious, and have many memorable and quotable moments. It feels like watching a movie (spoilers,  There are some anime-like cutscenes, following the original 'Elysian Tail' movie style. Both the movie and this game is the same creator  )I love this game, i love the people behind it (one person doing the sole programming and graphics for over 4 years of development, plus music composer group, and voice actors)I only wish the game had some sorta replay value (besides replaying the game in a higher difficulty), but overall, this game was a wonderful experience.Get this game, it's awesome, i demand it!EDIT: Now nominated for a Steam Award!

Posted: February 8, 2014
												A very fun game, though not a particularly challenging one.Combat is very responsive and flows nicely; almost too nicely since you'll very rarely get hit. I would recommend playing the game on Hardcore difficulty so its at least a little challenging at the start, though it quickly becomes a cake walk anyways once you level up a bit. Later on in the game, after you've torn through thousands of basic enemies, some more interesting enemies start showing up, such as one that can only be hurt by projectile attacks and one that can mimic your aerial dust storm ability. Unfortunately, by that point, you're so ludicrously overpowered, that it doesn't matter, even on hardcore difficulty.But while it's a very easy game, its also a very fun one. You can impale enemies, launch then into the air, then turn into a tornado of slashing chaos and launch into the air before sending the poor creature back down to earth. And then you zap everyone on the screen with lightning.So if you're looking for a challenging game to test your skill against, look somewhere else; but if you just want to pass the time with some fun hack'n'slash action against hordes of hapless opponents, you could certainly do a lot worse than this. And that's really the whole point of video games, isn't it: FUN.

Posted: July 20, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a wonderful experience of a Side Scrolling Hack N' Slash game, and I'm here to tell you why.The game starts off with you playing as Dust, a... furry (?) who woke up in the middle of the forests who dealt with amnesia, and is awfully confused on whom he is, and is confronted by Fidget the Nimbat, and Ahrah the Sword. You set out on a perilious journey to discover Dust's past and face all kinds of wicked monsters across the world.The game features extremely satisfying and smooth combat despite it being limited to 2D, yet, it plays so well.The game's combo system works by pressing two buttons, one for slashing, and another for extra combos. You gain new abilities, most likely to help you in enemy confrontrations when you play more of the game.The game world is absolutely lovely and beautiful to look at, as well as the scenery you come across. It is quite expansive, as you head out to new areas to explore the world.The combat can sometimes get repetitive and tiring after a while, as the fight mechanics do not change, but the game can make up for this with it's wonderful speed and fluent style of gameplay, that happens so quickly. It is very awesome.The difficulty is not in any way lacking, unless if you have mastered the combat to the extreme, as it allows you to pick which difficulty you would prefer, easy, moderate, or hard.Sent on:3:02 pmThere are many characters and side quests to tackle on if you do not want to try and finish the main game's storyline, as they give you time to explore the world for secrets, treasures, and quests to start on your own time.It features a nice quick leveling up system, that once you've gained enough experience points, you can choose a stat you'd like to improve, as it keeps the game extremely fresh and impressive.The game allows you to craft new items to your liking that has stats you'd generally prefer to have and use, such as armor, sword buffs, pendents, rings, etc.Dust An Elysian Tail may seem short to some who've played and decided to go on a quick speed-through, but it is a fun experience nevertheless and I suggest buying at full price to support the developer 100%, since a lot of love andeffort to making this game. Kudos.HOPING SEQUEL COMES OUT IN THE FUTURE! MUAAAAAAH!

Posted: December 24, 2014
												I orriginally played this on the X-Box 360 and bought it here so access to the game will outlive my x-box (will likely purchase AGAIN if it makes it onto PS Vita) Dust is an oft times frenetic side scrolling beatemup with an aluring story that I wont spoil.   The game play is basic on the surface but has more depth involving the interplay between the proteganist Dust and his charmingly offbeat  and sometimes cowardly sidekick Fidgit.  Infact the dialogue between them makes the game, (especially some of her 4th wall breaking commentary such as an early fight when the talking sword Dust carries tells him to use the skill she has learned and Fidget tells him to just mash buttons).. Dust has mostly close up sword skills with the expected levels of upgrades and advancements, Fidget takes the place of you magic system with some impressive sometimes screen clearing special attacks.I don't recall a point where I felt the game was unfairly difficult, and found it highly enjoyable..Pick it up sometime :)

Posted: January 15, 2016
												First and Foremost, while there are a large amount of support staff, this game is largely the result one man's work.  Dean Dodrill did a phenominal job bringing this to life and while I'm usually not willing to give leniance to games simply because of they have a smaller dev team, I feel this game is worthy of an exception.The game is quite pretty and you can tell that Dean's first love is animation.  There is beautiful detail in a lot of the work and the environments ooze character and personality.  It's the kind of art direction that a larger studio would never really get 'right' because Dust's art is the result of a singular vision, not designed by a committee.  While the artistic front is not as polished and as jaw-dropping as say, Ori and the Blind Forest, it's definitely a strong point and again, for a single person who kinda just wanted to do animation, it's nothing short of fantastic.The combat is fluid, fair, and manages to feel pretty good.  The mechanics follow a lot of the standards that are expected in a action-combat game.  While the game feels pretty good to play, it lacks depth and has a lot of contextual actions that trade fine control for ease of combat.I bought this game because I wanted to find a 2D Devil May Cry and I learned a something playing through Dust:  DMC is hard to make.A game like DMC4 has systems are ultra tight and provide a platform for the player to do amazing things if you invest the time to learn them.  It has a skill ceiling that might as well be infinite due to the shear number of options you have as a player, and as difficulty ramps up, the game will expect you to use those options with a kind of fluency that takes hours and hours to master.  Dust does not have that kind of depth.  A lot of the combat systems aren't perfect.  Attacks in the air kind of auto-target anything close by, sacrificing player control at times when you'd rather not.  You can lock almost every enemy into an infinite loop of uninterruptable damage in a couple different ways, none of which are terribly difficult to perform.  Bosses have pretty predictable patterns that are easy to abuse and instead of fighting a dynamic fight that requires action and reaction, you are kinda stuck just doing 'the thing that works'.There are a few other problems with the systems in place.  Attacks that would kill you will leave you at 1 HP as long as you have at least 50% of the HP the attack would do.  This means, that healing past that threshold is a mistake, and that max HP is effectively worthless.  You get bonus XP based on your combo, but you can farm combo with your secondary attack from your friendly NPC and since combo isn't damage, but rather hit count, it is in your best interest to keep her damage as low as possible while you just spam a screenwide AoE, allowing you to easily push your combo to several hundred with just a handful of monsters on the screen, which translates to easy levels.  There are a lot of counterintuitive systems that are ripe for abuse.I was kinda hoping for a game with as tight of design as a modern DMC and I didn't really get that, but regardless, the game is a fine entry in it's own right.  Despite their flaws, the mechanics aren't frustrating and as long as you go into the game with the right expectations, You'll find an enjoyable experience.

Posted: May 22, 2015
												A simple 15-20 hr side-scrolling action game. A Metroidvania with anthros.tl;dr review:Play it but mute the voice. Longer full review below.I initially bought it mostly because I heard it was made by one guy, and the fact I love metroid games. Well technically, this game is made by one guy + a bunch of voice actors, but it really should have been made by one guy and no voice actors. More on that later. I was rather curious seeing how a single guy could write, programme, draw/animate a game all by himself. In terms of combat and enemy variety and overall gameplay, I say this game is pretty great in that department. Dust: An Elysian tail gives you basic sword attacks like a simple side-scrolling action game, but it includes some Devil May Cry-like combos including the ability to launch enemies a helm breaker style attack an a parry system similar to like in Metal Gear Rising using holding the light attack while facing your enemy at the correct timing. The defining characteristic of the combat system is the dust storm, where dust spins his sword wildly that when combined by his little friend Fidget's elemental attacks results in a giant storm of elemental fury, projectiles flying everywhere, chain lightning, pillars of flame. My only complain is that there are only three elements, not a lot of variety there.The difficulty of the game is weird though. RPGs always come in three forms, either they start really easy and become insanely difficult in the end, forcing you to grind, or, you start hard and end the game steam rolling everything even the boss (Oh Skyrim is the biggest culprit of this). This game contains RPG levelling and one that makes the difficulty that goes easy>hard>easy. The final boss was more of an endurance run rather than an actual challenge with 4 phases which is... too long. You might say he's the final boss, it should be long, yes, but it also wasn't challenging, so I was basically waiting to win and wasn't anywhere near death or in need to use a healing item (which the game generously drops a bunch). With the large amount of enemies you fight leading up to the final boss, you're gonna overlevel, and that certainly did not help. Still, besides the final boss, the first three bosses, when you aren't actually overleveled, did in fact gave me a challenge. Thus so this is another one of those games where the final boss ends up being easier than the first. But no matter, the other bosses had clever patterns and were a decent enough challenge so I'll let that easy final boss part go and give this gameplay a 9.Combat and Gameplay 9/10Story is.... ehhh. Of course it's not Lord of the Rings, I'm not expecting an epic story, but well, forget it. The gameplay alone is good, just don't bother with the story, it's not important nor a deciding factor of buying this game.Story - whatever/10Level Design is an important thing in a metroidvania game, and overall I did not feel that this game had a very good level design. It's really straightforward, so much so it's kinda boring. The world is put together with an overworld map connecting everything, and if you ever played Castlevania: Order of Ecclessia and found how straightforward and boring the levels are, well there you go. There's not a lot of branching paths and most of the secrets are just so obvious I wouldn't even call it a secret anyway. Remember that feeling when you first broke the glass with a power bomb in super metroid? or when you discovered the area where the rain mysteriously stopping in mid air is actually an invisible floating platform? Of course, I'm not saying the game is just a straight line every level, neither was Castlevania: OoE. All I'm saying is, this game didn't give me any real sense of discovery like when I'm walking through Dracula's castle in SotN. Many of the collectibles are just in too obvious locations.On the other hand, the game does have some interesting platforming sections. Some good some bad. They're not the Tower of death level of difficulty or cleverness with moving platforms, spinning blades, spikes and medusa heads of course, but it is a good enough challenge in their own right.Level design - 7/10Sound, music is good, lots of catchy tunes but the problem is.... the voice acting... oh no... Nooo.. Just nooo............ This is why this one man game... should have remained a one man game. The voice acting is anywhere from acceptable to just plain awful. And I'm not talking about Fidget which many other reviewers seem to hate. For me, Fidget (and Dust actually) sound okay. But Ginger is bad. She's suppose to be sad and depressed as the story claims, except every time she talks, she sounds indifferent, like a robot, not giving a damn, even when a certain character supposedly died at the end, she was like "oh no what do I do....??". Like I said, the music, is pretty good. The voice acting? NOPE, NOPE, NOPE.Overall 8/10. A solid side scrolling action game. The Combat is awesome, the enemies and bosses are really clever. The dust storm mechanics just makes fighting in this game fun as hell. The only real downside of this game is the voice acting, and that's it.
